Headline: British American Tobacco To Pull Out Of North Korea -Paper
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--British American Tobacco (BTI) is pulling out of North Korea, but insisted the move had nothing to do with political pressure, The Guardian in London reported Saturday.   The newspaper said the world's second largest cigarette group had agreed to sell its 60% share in Taesong BAT, its joint venture in Pyongyang with state-owned Korea Sogyong Chonyonmul Trading Operation.   According to The Guardian, BAT is selling the stake to SUTL, a Singaporean investment group that will manufacture and sell its Craven A brand under license in North Korea. The price has not been agreed yet but will be small in relation to the group, the newspaper said.   According to the newspaper a BAT spokeswoman denied that the company had come under pressure to leave North Korea and insisted it was "a purely commercial decision."   Newspaper Web site: http://www.guardian.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9259     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 13:32 ET (17:32 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/11) Victoria's Real Secret
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Michael Santoli   Limited Brands has lately become even more limited -- but in a good way. Its narrowing of its focus to two major retail brands should pay off for investors, even if the immediate outlook for sales growth is choppy amid signs of consumers' spending fatigue and a short-term bulge in inventories.   The two chains that now drive the company -- Victoria's Secret and Bath & Body Works -- dominate their categories, enjoy impressive profit margins and are in niches with attractive long-term prospects. Shares of Limited Brands (ticker: LTD) also offer a play on a possible investor-friendly financial restructuring, an intriguing retail-services business and an implied call option on a handful of new store concepts.   But first, investors might have to wait out a transition year as Victoria's Secret faces comparisons with strong 2006 sales trends and spends heavily to enlarge its stores, raising the chance that an already skeptical Wall Street could pan month-to-month results and grow hostile. A sharp pullback in the stock, attractively valued at a recent 26, probably would be a gift of a buying opportunity. A 2% rise in same-store sales for May, reported Thursday, beat forecasts of a small decline, and seemed to quell some analysts' fears that a recent run of sluggish sales and shrinking margins at Victoria's Secret would snowball.   The leaner corporate profile results from Limited's agreement last month to sell two-thirds of its Express apparel business to private-equity firm Golden Gate Capital for $431 million, a deal that would bring Limited pretax cash proceeds of $548 million after Express pays the parent a $117 million debt-financed dividend. Limited is paring its exposure to lower-margin and slower-growth clothing lines. The company is now exploring options for its barely profitable Limited stores.   Limited Brands is using the Express money to repurchase up to $500 million in stock, a significant percentage of its $10.6 billion market capitalization.   In largely exiting the apparel business, Limited has become a play on body consciousness and self-pampering, selling lingerie and lotions, bustiers and bath salts --  categories that are in a cultural sweet spot.   Yet there is significant skepticism on Wall Street that Limited can deliver. That's why its stock price sits 20% below its late-2006 high and trades at a modest 14 times expected 2008 earnings. Limited's enterprise value (market cap plus net debt) is less than eight times earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (Ebitda, a measure of cash flow), barely that of struggling retailers such as Gap Stores (GPS). This, in a market where unremarkable retailers have been taken private at valuations near 10 times Ebitda.   Skeptics fixate on the erosion in Victoria's Secret's sales growth and profit margins. As Morgan Stanley analyst Michelle Clark wrote in downgrading Limited to the equivalent of a Hold on May 29, "The pace and degree of operating-margin deterioration" is "concerning." Margins at the chain slid by three percentage points, into the mid-teens, from the second quarter of last year through this year's first three months.   It's unclear whether competitors' initiatives in pushing lingerie and "lounge-wear" have weakened Victoria's Secret's hold on its customers. Gap, JC Penney (JCP) and others are targeting this area heavily.   Limited executives declined to speak with Barron's. And they've perhaps turned off investors and analysts by failing to clearly explain what's hurt Victoria's Secret. Comments to analysts by the division's CEO, Sharen Turney, in last quarter's earnings conference call were dishearteningly obscure. Discussing Secret Embrace, a hit bra line, Turney said that Limited's marketing message "was confusing the customer about, OK, is Secret Embrace a technology, is it a sub-brand?" And later: "We have done a lot of hindsighting and what we have also found out is that really the customer is not as much about the technology, but the technology is a driver to the benefit of the bra." Got that?   If this failed to illuminate just why sales fell short, it did succeed in reminding investors that, far from being a steady seller of staple undergarments, Victoria's Secret is rather hit-product-driven. This has historically been a good thing, as the unit consistently led in innovation and function, not to mention eye-grabbing marketing.   Yet the margin declines are partly explainable by less worrisome trends. The company is spending significantly to enlarge 80% of its 1,005 Victoria's Secret stores by 50% over five years. And stores' profitability has jumped as they've been converted.   A shift in the sales mix toward the lower-margin Pink brand of casual "dorm-wear" or "lounge-wear" has pressured profits. Yet this brand has gone from zero to $700 million in sales in two years since its launch, in a blockbuster organic brand extension.   Thursday's report showed that same-store sales growth at Victoria's Secret has revived; Limited had encouraging words about mid-single-digit projected growth in June, based on early trends.   At the same time, the Express sale and possible divestiture of Limited stores is prompting a review of overhead, which should help margins.   Then there's a Limited subsidiary called Mast Industries, which essentially brokers the manufacture of clothing in Asia and elsewhere for U.S. retailers. Initially an in-house utility for Limited's chains, it also services former Limited-owned companies such as Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF). It will continue to source Express following the sale.   Mast is ramping up third-party sales, according to a write-up by a fund manager on the invitation-only idea forum www.valueinvestorsclub.com, who suggests that Limited as a whole is worth $34. The only publicly traded peer, Hong Kong's Li & Fung (0494.Hong Kong), trades above 25 times Ebitda. Limited hasn't discussed long-term plans for Mast, but it could conceivably grow into a stand-alone business.   Limited is hearing calls from investors to boost its modest debt levels to repurchase even more stock. Limited could add some debt without pushing its credit rating below investment-grade. It's worth noting that in the first quarter, close to a dozen catalyst-seeking hedge funds initiated positions in Limited stock, according to recent filings, indicating that some arguably smart money smells value (assuming they're still in after the Express sale).   The stock also includes a lottery ticket -- Chairman Leslie Wexner's knack for developing phenomenally successful retail concepts, with current incubating ideas including C.O. Bigelow (a beauty and personal-care product chain), White Barn Candle (home fragrance and decor shops) and others.   With downside risk contained by solid asset values and several potential upside catalysts, Limited stock should be back in fashion in about a year.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/11) The Trader: Where Have We Seen This Movie Before?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kopin Tan   Summer is the season for block-buster sequels on the big screen. But traders watching their computer screens last week can be forgiven for the nagging sense of deja vu.   Consider the plot summary: The time is early June. An inflation scare yanks the 10-year Treasury yield up toward 5.25%. An already-nervous stock market watching the bond market for cues scrambles for the exits, and the Standard & Poor's 500 index tumbles 3%. Where have we seen this movie before? Why,it's the summer of . . . 2006!   This year's version, however, features some key variations: The slide came right after stocks reached record peaks Monday, whereas last year's June drop had followed a first wave of selling in late May. This time around, inflation fears are stoked by robust overseas growth and worries about the infiltration of global inflation. The European Central Bank last week raised rates to a six-year high of 4%. The U.S. economy has logged a few more quarters of sluggish growth, and the bull run, while tenacious, is a crucial year older.   Stocks' midweek decline was their sharpest since late February, and each of the major benchmarks fell 3% or more over three days. But by Friday, money managers who recall how the 2006 June swoon had played out stepped in to buy, and the bounce provided some reprieve heading into the weekend intermission.   Rate-sensitive stocks like utilities, real-estate-investment trusts and financials suffered the worst drubbing, while cyclical and technology stocks proved more resilient.   The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended the week down 244, or 1.8%, to 13,424. The S&P 500 lost 29, or 1.9%, to 1508. The Nasdaq Composite Index slipped 40, or 1.5%, to 2574, while the Russell 2000 index of small stocks fell 18, or 2.1%, to 835. The 10-year yield climbed to a 10-month high of 5.12%.   So will the past indeed be prologue? The "this time is no different" crowd has recent history on its side. Since 2004, there have been only two other occasions when the Dow had fallen by more than 80 points for three straight days. Both times, the Dow bounced back resoundingly with gains of 2.6% and 4.7% 15 days later, notes Birinyi Associates.   Tobias Levkovich, Citigroup's chief U.S. equity strategist, believes there is a better-than-90% probability for U.S. stocks to be higher in six months. After all, valuations are still attractive and sentiment nowhere near excessively bullish, with last week's rapid mood swing providing further proof "of a cautious mindset and pretty timid conviction in the stock market rally thus far in 2007."   Still, there are worrying signs that bear watching. The market's unconvincing breadth quickly turned ugly midweek. Peter Green, Northeast Research's chief technical analyst, sees in the stalling Dow Jones Transportation Average limited legs for any short-term market bounce. The benchmark had flirted with 5050; if it were to fall below 5000 in the coming sessions, it could well slip-slide toward its 200-day average near 4800, and that could take the Dow Jones Industrial Average down toward 12,480.   Higher bond yields also loom as a potential villain. A booming global economy and rising prices are pushing up global bond yields. "And since the U.S. needs to compete against yields elsewhere to fund our $800 billion-plus current-account deficit, our yields are rising even as domestic economic growth slowed down," notes Dover Management's chief investment officer, Doug Cliggott.   Fueled by cheap borrowing costs, U.S. companies' profit margins have expanded in recent years -- with that margin expansion closely tied to debt growth. But "debt growth peaked at 9.4% in the first quarter of 2006 and has since slowed sharply," Cliggott noted. "The increase in bond yields we are seeing now is likely to put further downward pressure on debt growth" -- and with it, corporate profit margins.   Jack Ablin, Harris Private Bank's chief investment officer, says the stock market is "still undervalued relative to bonds with the 10-year Treasury yield below 5.5%." But he would not be surprised if that drifted toward 5.8% in 12 months. Ablin expects stocks' high single-digit returns this year to dwindle to "a smidgen" by early next year, especially as the election draws closer. Large stocks, with their compelling valuation and overseas revenue, will hold up better, but smaller stocks could be "toast."   Last week, Goldman Sachs' economists say they no longer expect the Federal Reserve to cut interest rates in 2007 (they had previously forecast cuts of three-quarters of a percentage point this year).   Sure, there are those who argue that the economy has grown less sensitive to rate changes. Interest rates also may not rise enough to retard economic growth. And the market remains awash in liquidity.   Just last week, David Robinson, the former San Antonio Spurs all-star, said he plans to start a $250 million private-equity fund that will target "socially conscious" companies. Last month's contemporary art sales in New York saw more than 120 artists' records smashed. And "For the Love of God," a human skull that the artist Damien Hirst encrusted with $28 million worth of diamonds, commands a marked-up price tag of $100 million. Are these mounting signs of peak-market excess or reassuring reminders of liquidity? Stay tuned.     Is it me, or do the gathered guests seem more excited about the union of TD Ameritrade than the groom?   Ameritrade shares (ticker: AMTD) have jumped 33% in the seven weeks since the discount brokerage was flagged here as overlooked and ripe for a merger. Last week, the shares popped on news that the hedge funds SAC Capital Advisors and JANA Partners had amassed an 8.4% stake and were prodding Ameritrade toward the altar.   Management's response so far has coyly straddled the line between yes and no. CEO Joe Moglia says that hedge-fund pressure won't sway its strategy. But he also claims that the firm is always mulling its options and "talking to a lot of people all the time."   The market evidently relishes the prospect of a union. Shares of Ameritrade and E-Trade Financial (ETFC) both rallied on the news, even after the far-larger Charles Schwab (SCHW) said  it isn't interested. With growth stalling, cutting back overlapping branches, call centers and advertising could generate annual cost savings of nearly $500 million in a merger with E-Trade, for example.   But no trip to the altar can occur without the blessing of Toronto-Dominion Bank (TD), which owns 40% of the outstanding shares (and the Ricketts family, who control 20%).   In fact, the hedge funds see TD as such an obstacle that their May 29 missive to the Ameritrade board lobbied first for TD's removal from the proceedings even before they made a case for a merger. Among other things, they see a disconnect between the interests of the Canadian bank and Ameritrade stockholders -- with TD representatives putting the Canadian bank's strategic desires "above their duty to obtain the best result for all of TD Ameritrade's shareholders," said SAC's Steven Cohen and JANA's Barry Rosenstein in their joint letter.   TD shares had begun to run up in late-May before the news. It now has four options: It might do nothing and wait out the hubbub. It can go along with a merger that dilutes its stake. It can also sell off its Ameritrade holding. Both the second and third alternatives aren't exactly palatable since they leave TD with a diminished piece -- or none at all -- of its U.S. growth platform, says Blackmont Capital analyst Brad Smith.   The remaining choice is for TD to buy out the 60% piece of Ameritrade that it doesn't  own. Ameritrade now trades at 16 times forward earnings, and given its opportunity cost for enhancing value in a merger, Smith estimates that TD may have to cough up at least $25 a share -- or about $8.9 billion -- for the remaining stake. "While that may be its ultimate longer-term objective, it's not something TD wants to do right now," Smith says.   With a stalemate looking likely, the hedge funds fired off another retort Friday. "Nothing . . . changes our belief that the time to enter into a value-maximizing strategic combination is now, or our belief that the interests of Toronto-Dominion Bank conflict with those of all other shareholders," say SAC and JANA.   Expect TD and Ameritrade to stall and the hedge funds to apply more pressure. Your move, Messrs Cohen and Rosenstein.     The S&P 500 wasn't the only one to recently reclaim its seven-year peak. Quietly but no less spectacularly, Amazon.com (AMZN) has returned to its March 2000 glory.   Shares of the online retailer have vaulted 74% in less than two months after the company reported strong first-quarter earnings in late April that surprised Wall Street. More important, operating margins have turned up, and Amazon predicts easing capital spending after years of heavy research and development commitments. And CEO Jeff Bezos' recent promise to increase investment in China, its fastest-growing market, lifted shares above 73.   Investors relish the prospect of growth  -- particularly of the international variety --  as U.S. economic expansion slows. Amazon has become the go-to retailer on the World Wide Web, with 46% of revenue earned outside North America, and further margin expansion has converts hailing an era of Amazonian domination. But how much good news is priced into the stock?   With its rally, shares have zoomed past the recently raised 12-month price targets of even the more optimistic analysts. They trade today at 123 times what Amazon earned over the past year, or 57 times forward earnings. The latter far exceeds multiples of less than 20 times for eBay (EBAY) and 27 times for Google (GOOG), themselves no shrinking violets of the Internet.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/11) The Striking Price: A Growing Chorus Of Bud Frogs
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Steven M. Sears   Talking smack and drinking beer. they're good ways to waste time, and Wall Street thinks it may have discovered how to make them profitable. Last week, Pershing Square Capital Management, which buys big stock interests in moribund companies and browbeats management into making decisions that increase the stock price, let leak that it was raising a $2 billion war chest to buy a controlling interest in an unidentified company with a market capitalization of $30 billion to $40 billion.   Almost immediately, the options market pointed to Budweiser.   One way for investors to get in on the action: Sell overpriced one- and three-month call options on Anheuser-Busch (ticker: BUD) to speculate on an anticipated shakedown from some yakety-yak hedge fund.   The implied volatility of Budweiser's options that expire in one month, and three months shot to one year-highs and are now among the most expensive in the entire consumer-staple sector. The other overpriced options are Kroger (KR), Kraft Foods (KFT) and Safeway (SWY). All are takeover targets because they have what leveraged buyout funds need: strong, predictable cash flows, and straightforward balance sheets that can be leveraged.   The Bud bid is not certain; one newspaper listed 31 companies that could prove attractive to the hedge fund. Bud's chief financial officer, who is probably having a drink this weekend to relax, declined to comment on the speculation, according to Dow Jones Newswires.   The options market, however, is speaking as loudly as Budweiser's famous talking frogs. Market makers increased the volatility of Bud's one-month and three-month options to 26%, and 23%, respectively. This telegraphs expectations that something happens soon.   The skew of Bud's options -- essentially the price difference between puts and calls -- is unusual. Bud's calls are more expensive than its puts, another sign of the options market's expectations Bud's stock price may rise. Miller Tabak & Co., a boutique brokerage with many hedge-fund clients, recommends selling Bud's richly priced calls as long as the volatility remains high.   Many traders reflexively sell high-volatility options because volatility acts like a rubber band. After it stretches out, it snaps back to its normal level. Trading on volatility is harder than that analogy suggests, because it's so hard to predict when volatility will normalize. Sometimes it goes higher before going lower.   What is certain in this uncertain trade is that Budweiser's management is under serious pressure to perform, even if the boorish hedge fund ultimately browbeats another company.   Budweiser has strong cash flows, a healthy dividend, and management is just starting to leverage its balance sheet before someone else does it for them.   The leverage is a likely defensive sign that Budweiser realizes it's a takeover target. This is probably a self-fulfilling prophecy, and one that will prove profitable for traders and investors. The implied volatility on Budweiser one-, three- six- and 12-month options contracts are all trading at one-year highs. And that's something worth toasting.   ---   E-mail: steven.sears@barrons.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: ICICI Bk Local Share Issue Likely In INR900-INR960 Band - TV
Story: MUMBAI (Dow Jones)--India's ICICI Bank (532174.BY), the country's largest private sector bank by assets, is likely to price local shares under its follow-on public offer in the INR900 to INR960 per share band, reported television channel CNBC-TV18 Saturday, quoting unnamed sources.   A person familiar with the issue had earlier told Dow Jones Newswires the bank is likely to complete its INR201.25 billion (around $5 billion) share issue in the domestic and overseas markets by the end of June to fund its capital adequacy requirements ahead of switching to Basel-II norms in March 2008.   The television report didn't mention any pricing for the overseas offering.   On the Bombay Stock Exchange, ICICI Bank shares closed down 0.6% at INR903.60 Friday.     -By Tuhin Kar, Dow Jones Newswires;  91 22 2288 4212; tuhin.kar@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 05:27 ET (09:27 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/11) Barron's Online: Load Up
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Steven M. Sears   Smith & Wesson is better known for making Dirty Harry's .44 magnum revolver than as a stock that's worth a shot.   But that deserves to change.   For one thing, the shares have had a stellar run in the past two years, going from about $3.50 to $14. Over the past year alone they're up 90%, and they could go higher because Smith & Wesson (ticker: SWHC) is on the cusp of entering new markets with good growth prospects.   Moreover, a management team trained at companies like Black & Decker has successfully turned around the company.   Smith & Wesson is introducing new rifles and shotguns, whose combined markets are 80% larger than that of the main driver of the company's fortunes, handguns.   The company also is working to regain its leadership in the law-enforcement market, which it lost years ago.   "The bottom line is 100% profit growth for fiscal 2008," says Mike Golden, Smith & Wesson's chief executive. "We've added seven points to gross margin, and opportunities remain for margin enhancement."   Those strong words are not lost on private-equity investors, who are surprisingly active in the gun sector and could yet take aim on Smith & Wesson.   To be sure, Smith & Wesson stock is expensive: It's trading at 23.5 times its projected fiscal 2008 earnings, according to Thomson Financial. And small-cap stocks generally carry more risks than large-caps.   Litigation is also a risk, as is a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into the company's restatement of financial documents.   But this stock is worth owning for aggressive growth investors.   Smith & Wesson is so well-regarded by gun aficionados that a 2004 survey commissioned by the company showed they preferred its revolvers, pistols, tactical rifles, shotguns, hunting rifles, security systems and ammunition to those of other makers. At the time, however, Smith & Wesson sold little more than pistols and revolvers.   Golden saw this research as an opportunity to add new product lines, in keeping with customers' lofty expectations of the brand.   The company has aggressively introduced new pistols, rifles and shotguns. The M&P semiautomatic pistol line, for example, competes with Glock, an Austrian-made polymer pistol that replaced Smith & Wesson handguns as the standard sidearm at most police departments. The company's biggest opportunity is the "long-gun" market, which includes shotguns and rifles. Entering this $1.1 billion market, 80% larger than the U.S. handgun market, could be a good catalyst for the stock , says Cai von Rumohr, a Cowen & Co. analyst.   So far, the company's new strategy is producing results. Management advised investors in March that fiscal 2008 sales should total about $320 million, a 42% increase over the previous year's level. Net income is expected to total $27 million, or 60 cents a diluted share. So despite their nice run in the past year, Smith & Wesson shares still have firepower.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/11) Asian Trader: In China, Hong Kong Is The Better Bet
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Keri Geiger   Chinese shares have taken some wild rides lately, tempting bargain hunters. But to find value, don't look on the mainland; look in Hong Kong.   From Jan. 1 to May 29, Chinese shares catapulted 62% to a high for the year. Subsequently, after Beijing tripled its stamp duty on trades to cool the market and dampen rampant speculation, stocks began toppling. On June 7, the Shanghai Composite index closed at 3,890.8, up 45.4% for the year and 10.2% below the May 29 high.   But investors should remain wary of Shanghai, which now deserves the "Wild Wild East" moniker once applied to Hong Kong. In fact, shares in Shanghai, China's premier stock exchange, have more than tripled over the past 18 months.   The problem is that much of this enormous growth is somewhat artificial. Yes, billions of dollars in liquidity are sloshing around, as everyone from teachers to taxi drivers bets on equities.   However, by law, mainland residents can invest only in domestic A shares traded in Shanghai and Shenzhen, and don't have access to stocks listed in Hong Kong, including H shares and red-chips. Red-chips are Hong Kong-registered, but controlled by mainland shareholders, while Class H shares are Hong Kong-listed companies registered and based in China.   Notes Wilfred Sit, regional chief investment officer for Asia Pacific at Mirae Asset Global Investment Management: "Right now, the A-share market is largely closed to foreign investors and it is difficult for domestic money to get out of China. So you have billions of dollars trapped in that market, which pushes up prices."   He adds that the government's effort to discourage speculation on the property sector -- formerly the most overheated part of China's domestic economy -- has funneled a lot of investment toward Shanghai stocks.   Jonathan Anderson, chief regional economist at UBS in Hong Kong, points to speculation and government actions as key factors in the massive rise of Chinese shares.   Since Beijing lifted its moratorium on new stock listings in mid-2006, billions of dollars of new shares from state-owned Chinese companies have flooded the market. Some of these companies executed dual-share offerings, with a portion of their equity sold as A shares and the remainder as H shares in Hong Kong. The rise in the A-share market overall has led to big valuation disparities.   These days, A shares boast a 50% average weighted premium over H shares, according to JPMorgan. As of June 6, mega-mainland lender ICBC's A shares traded at a 26% premium over its H shares and Bank of China's A shares commanded a 39% premium to its H shares, JPM says. The average price/earnings ratio for H shares is 20.05 times current year earnings, versus 40.38 for the Shanghai Composite.     Do Shanghai's rampant volatility and soaring share prices signal a bubble? Most analysts doubt that. Says Shanghai-based Chris Ruffle, who runs the China Fund at investment house Martin Currie: "It is not like the equity bubble in Japan in the 1980s, where investors could sell Japanese shares and swap into other markets. People are acting rationally, and you are getting an explosion in earnings."   Still, wary fund managers favor Hong Kong. "We prefer H shares over A shares because of price differentials.' says Anderson. "The H shares are still better-quality companies. The A shares have a . . . fat tail of less profitable companies."   Jing Ulrich, chairman of China equities at JPMorgan Chase, says there are still buying opportunities in the H-share market. She views coal producer China Shenhua Energy (ticker: 1088.HK) as attractive, owing to strong coal prices, robust demand and highly efficient operations. She also likes Hong Kong-listed Sinofert (0297.HK), a leader in the domestic fertilizer market, with a growing market share.   Hugh Simon, CEO of Hamon Investment Group and portfolio manager for the Dreyfus Premier Greater China Fund in Hong Kong, says since neither the Hang Seng Index nor the H-share index has moved up that much this year; this part of the China market isn't overheated. He likes China Travel (0308.HK), which is benefiting from China's growing tourism at home and abroad, and Dynasty Fine Wines (0828.HK), which is being boosted by increased domestic consumption.   Investors expect Hong Kong to continue delivering impressive returns, thanks to strong company fundamentals and earnings growth, coupled with China's red-hot economy.   Khiem Do, portfolio manager of the Asia Pacific Fund at Baring Asset Management in Hong Kong, expects the Hang Seng Index to jump another 8% to 10% this year, with earnings-per-share growth of 17% to 20%.   "The market returns and EPS growth should continue into next year," predicts Do.   ---   Keri Geiger, a former Dow Jones Newswires correspondent in Asia, currently is pursuing a graduate degree in the U.S.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : PepsiCo Announces Plan for Second Snack Plant in Russia
Story: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia, June 9 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- PepsiCo International is pleased to announce the selection of the town of Azov in the Rostov region as the planned location of its second snacks manufacturing site in Russia, paving the way for an investment of around $170 million over the next five years into the region and the creation of approximately 1000 new jobs.     PepsiCo's decision to build a second snacks manufacturing site comes five years following the decision to invest over $160 million in its first site and related agricultural programmes in Kashira near Moscow in 2002.  The Kashira plant is now one of the largest and most modern snack manufacturing sites both in Russia and continental Europe.     Since 2002, the market for PepsiCo snacks products has grown quickly and the plant at Kashira, which employs around 1600 workers from the area, is now at full capacity.  The new facility in Rostov will provide opportunity for the company to expand sales throughout Russia.     Rostov was chosen as the ideal location for the second site due to its optimal access to customer distribution as well as availability of land and utility connections.     PepsiCo's investment planned for Rostov will also include investments in agricultural programmes in the area which will provide local potato farmers with the tools and training to increase yields and grow superior quality potatoes.  Since beginning its snacks business in Russia in 2002, PepsiCo has invested substantially in local farming with the result that only four years after the start of the programme, 80% of all potatoes used by the Kashira plant are sourced locally, with plans to reach 100% in the next few years.     Speaking in St. Petersburg at a formal signing of the letter of intent with Governor Vladimir Chub of Rostov, Michael White, Vice Chairman of PepsiCo and CEO of PepsiCo International, said: "I am delighted to confirm our decision to invest in the Rostov region to build our second snacks manufacturing site in Russia.  Governor Chub and his team have provided every assistance to us in finding the best possible site and ensuring we will have access to the necessary infrastructure.  We are deeply proud of our business presence in Russia and today's decision is another vote of confidence from PepsiCo in the future growth and competitiveness of the Russian economy."     PepsiCo Russia Snacks General Manager, Paul Kiesler, said: "Our business in Russia has been growing quickly and the second site in Rostov will provide us with the necessary manufacturing capability to meet growing consumer demand for our products, both today and tomorrow."     PepsiCo's beverage operations in Russia began in 1974, with the opening of a bottling plant in Novorossyisk, which established Pepsi-Cola as the first Western branded consumer product to be produced in the country.  Today, PepsiCo and its strategic bottling and distribution partner, The Pepsi Bottling Group, provide direct and indirect employment for over 20,000 people in Russia and their products can be found in 96% of retail outlets across the country.  PepsiCo's beverage brands in Russia include Pepsi-Cola, Aqua Minerale, Tropicana, 7UP, Mirinda and Gatorade (sports drinks).  Its snacks brands include Lay's, Cheetos and Hrusteam, a recently-launched bread snack.     PepsiCo (NYSE: PEP) is one of the world's largest food and beverage companies, with 2006 annual revenues of more than $35 billion. The company operates in nearly 200 countries, and employs more than 168,000 people worldwide.  Its principal businesses include: Frito-Lay snacks, Pepsi-Cola beverages, Gatorade sports drinks, Tropicana juices and Quaker foods. The PepsiCo portfolio includes 17 brands that generate $1 billion or more each in annual retail sales. PepsiCo's commitment to sustainable growth, defined as Performance with Purpose, is focused on generating healthy financial returns while giving back to communities the company serves. This includes meeting consumer needs for a spectrum of convenient foods and beverages, replenishing the environment through water, energy and packaging initiatives, and supporting its employees through a diverse and inclusive environment that recruits and retains world-class talent.  The company is listed on the Dow  Jones North America Sustainability Index.   For more information, please visit www.pepsico.com.    SOURCE  PepsiCo International       /CONTACT: Dick Detwiler, PepsiCo International, U.S., +1-914-253-2725      /Web site: http://www.pepsi.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 06:34 ET (10:34 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(6/11) Follow-Up: For 1-800 Contacts, The Vision Pays Off
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrew Bary   People prone to losing their contact lenses got a nice break when 1-800 Contacts went into business a decade ago. The company brought down the costs of the slippery little things as it carved out a niche as the country's leading direct seller of contact lenses.   Shareholders weren't as fortunate. When Barron's took a favorable look at the company in 2006, its stock (ticker: CTAC) was languishing around $13, hurt by ongoing losses in the firm's  overseas contact-lens-manufacturing business ("A Clearer Vision," May 22, 2006).   Stockholders got good news last week when the company agreed to a $340 million buyout from Fenway Partners, a private-equity firm. Fenway will pay $24.25 in cash for each share of 1-800 Contacts, a 21% premium above the closing share price of 20.08 on June 1. Shares were trading Friday at 23.91.   "It's a fair price," says Mario Cibelli, who runs Marathon Partners, a New York investment firm that is one of the company's largest shareholders. Cibelli valued the company at $25 or more in the article last year. The purchase price of $340 million is equal to about 14 times projected 2007 pretax operating profits. 1-800-Contacts recently announced the sale of its overseas-manufacturing business along with its innovative flat-pack packaging for contact lenses.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: India Hindustan Zinc Cuts Zinc Price By INR1,900/Ton
Story: MUMBAI (Dow Jones)--India's Hindustan Zinc Ltd. (500188.BY) has cut zinc prices by INR1,900 ($41.14) a metric ton, or 1.1%, to INR171,600 per ton, the company said in a statement Saturday.   The largest zinc producer by volume also raised lead prices by INR700 a ton, or 0.7%, to INR105,500 per ton.   Both the changes are effective immediately, the statement said, without providing a reason for the changes.   Hindustan Zinc is a unit of London-listed Vedanta Resources PLC (VED.LN).     -By Tuhin Kar, Dow Jones Newswires;  91 22 2288 4212; tuhin.kar@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 05:35 ET (09:35 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/11) The Trader: Where Have We Seen -2-
Story: Amazon bulls argue that projected profits may still prove too low and will be lifted as skepticism dissipates. But the current valuation heaps pressure on Amazon to deliver steady margin expansion and outsize profit growth, and assumes ever-escalating demand for online goods and services. Amid such great expectations, the shrewd move might be to book some profits.   The surge has even attracted the attention of speculators who bet, not for the first time, that Amazon might use its inflated currency to plug the DVD-rental gap in its resume. As the broad market sold off last week, Netflix shares (NFLX) jumped 9%.   "Although we like the long-term prospects for Amazon, we believe the recent run-up in the stock has been overdone," says Dan Jones, who runs Blue Water Asset Management and www.e-bluewater.com. He suggests buying put spreads --  buying July 65 puts and selling July 60 puts -- to hedge against a short-term decline toward 60.   ---   E-mail: kopin.tan@barrons.com   ---                          VITAL SIGNS                                 Friday's     Week's    Week's                                Close       Change    % Chg. Headline: JJB Sports Founder Sells His Stake For GBP190 Mln -FT
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Dave Whelan, the founder of JJB Sports PLC (JJB.LN), has sold his 29% stake in the sportswear retailer to a consortium, the Financial Times in London reported Saturday.   Icelandic financial services company Exista Hf (EXISTA.IC) paid GBP190 million, or 275 pence per share, for the stake, together with Chris Ronnie, who used to work at Sports Direct International PLC (SPD.LN), the newspaper said. Ronnie will sit on JJB's board as deputy chief executive, it added.   After disposing of JJB shares in January, Whelan undertook not to sell any more for at least 12 months, according to the Financial Times.   However, Whelan informed the board of his decision to break that agreement on Wednesday - the same day the company issued a disappointing trading statement causing the shares to suffer their worst one-day fall since 1999, the newspaper added.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9319     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 12:32 ET (16:32 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Boeing, Aeroflot Sign Deal For 787-Dreamliner Planes -2-
Story: Both declined to disclose the financial detail of the transaction. List prices put the planes at between $140 million and $180 million each, although airlines generally negotiate a discount.   Aeroflot Chief Executive Valery Okulov said his company would take a syndicated loan, secured by the U.S. Export-Import Bank, to pay for the planes. He said Aeroflot has no debt burden at the moment, having cleared its balance sheet up over the last few years.   The deal will not affect existing orders with Airbus, a unit of EADS (5730.FR).   Separately, Okulov said Aeroflot's bid for troubled Italian carrier Alitalia SpA (AZA.MI) is now being backed by nine banks. Aeroflot is bidding jointly with Italian bank Unicredit (UC.MI).   Company Web sites: http://www.aerolfot.ru; http://www.boeing.com   -By Geoffrey T. Headline: Sistema Discussing Several Deals With China's ZTE >SSA.LN
Story: MOSCOW (Dow Jones)--Russian conglomerate AFK Sistema (SSA.LN) is negotiating several deals with Chinese telecommunications equipment manufacturer ZTE Corp. (000063.SZ), a company spokesman said Saturday.   "None of the deals have been closed," he said, adding that they involve Sistema's technology unit OAO Sitronics (SITR.RS) and are worth hundreds of millions of dollars.   Russian media reported in March that Sitronics had signed a memorandum of understanding with ZTE to form a manufacturing joint venture in the Chinese city of Shenzhen.   Company Web sites: http://www.zte.com.cn; www.sistema.com/   -By Will Bland, Dow Jones Newswires; +7 495 974 80 55; william.bland@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 11:16 ET (15:16 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Severstal CEO Mordashov Denies Talks With ThyssenKrupp -2-
Story: Russian news agency Interfax had reported Friday that Severstal was considering a number of strategic options related to its North American operations. Bankers in Moscow told Dow Jones Newswires that such a deal was unlikely due to Mordashov's frequent expression of his long-term commitment to the steel business. They also noted that a deal which took control of Severstal outside of Russia would be difficult politically.   Speculation on a possible deal revolves around the logic that Severstal's North American operations aren't as profitable as its domestic ones and that ThyssenKrupp has the same kind of advanced technology that Severstal was seeking in its abortive merger talks with Luxembourg-based Arcelor last year. Arcelor subsequently merged with Mittal Steel (MT).   Severstal is the third-largest producer of steel in North America, through its ownership of the former Rouge Industries, based in Dearborn, Mich.   Mordashov told reporters he had no plans to sell his North American assets.     Company Web site: http://www.severstal.ru     -By Geoffrey T. Smith, Dow Jones Newswires; +7 495 974 80 55; geoffrey.smith@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 02:37 ET (06:37 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Gazprom Won't Use Eni, Enel Option This Year - Vedomosti
Story: MOSCOW (Dow Jones)--Russian gas monopoly OAO Gazprom (GSPBEX.RS) will not use an option to buy 20% of OAO Gazprom Neft (SIBN.RS) from Italian energy companies Eni (E) and Enel SpA (EN) this year, the newspaper Vedomosti reported Saturday, citing Gazprom spokesman Sergei Kupriyanov.   An Eni spokeswoman declined to comment, the paper said.   In April, Eni and Enel won an auction for several assets belonging to bankrupt oil company OAO Yukos (YUKO.RS), including the stake in Gazprom Neft, which is already controlled by Gazprom.   Shortly afterwards, they said Gazprom has an option to buy most of the assets within two years.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.vedomosti.ru     -By Moscow Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +7 495 974 8055     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 03:00 ET (07:00 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(6/11) Plugged In: Cisco's Winning Telepresence
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   The long-awaited promise of virtual meetings has arrived, and it is only going to get better.   When I touted videoconferencing micro-cap Telanetix (ticker: TNXI.OB) two months ago (Plugged In, March 26), an editor asked: Haven't we been talking forever about how telecommunications technology is supposed to reduce business travel? Why now?   Excellent question, and I have an answer: It works.   Because of that column and a previous feature story on WebEx, whichis now a unit of Cisco Systems ("Why WebEx Will Shine," June 12, 2006), I've received a flock of offers to check out their competitors. There is something for everybody. At the lower end is WebEx, which is a desktop videoconferencing solution whose upside is its utility for workers to collaborate on different continents over the Web. Then there are Telanetix, Polycom (PLCM), Hewlett-Packard's super-high-end Halo (HPQ) and Cisco (CSCO), which developed its own higher-end solution prior to purchasing WebEx.   Last week, I gave Cisco's version a whirl, and it was impressive. I interviewed internal start-up chief Marthin DeBeer from San Francisco while he was in San Jose. By the end of our meeting, I had forgotten that we weren't in the same room. Honestly, it's that good.   "This isn't videoconferencing," DeBeer implored. Videoconferencing is so last century and usually implies a Web camera and a personal computer. This incarnation is called "telepresence," which sounds a little Star Trekkie but, understandably, tries to create distance from the industry's underachieving past. Like it or not, the moniker is here to stay. The first TelepresenceWorld trade show was held in San Diego last week.   An episode of the Fox television drama 24 gave folks a decent idea of how Cisco's system works. (You can watch it at www.telepresenceworld.com.) It requires a devoted room, with three high-def video panels (a one-panel option is also available), mounted cameras, screens for slides and a crescent-shaped meeting table. This setup gives you the feel of a conference room, allowing participants to look each other in the eye across the table and even hear voices coming directly from the person talking via an audio speaker under his or her image. Most important, the pictures and sound are crisp, without disruptive delays or glitchy interference. Cisco's 60-inch plasma screens boast high-definition TV technology that twice exceeds current industry standards. Lastly, it's CEO-proof: A meeting can be set up using Microsoft Outlook, and the call is launched by the touch of a button on a Cisco VoIP telephone.   Retail cost for a three-screen telepresence room is $299,000 and $79,000 for one panel, which is suited for executive offices (Cisco CEO John Chambers uses his frequently). The expense, including installation and upgrades, runs about $10,000 a month over three years, DeBeer says. What's more, it is an all-you-can-eat proposition, with no monthly fees because it runs on enterprise broadband. Still skeptical? Cisco claims it's eating its own dog food. It created 18 rooms for its own use 18 months ago and is up to 120, with each operating an average of five hours a day. Says DeBeer: "Telepresence is like chocolate. You must taste it to know what it's like." I must say, it tastes pretty good.   ---   E-mail: mark.veverka@barrons.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Universal Music To Sell DRM-Free Songs -Newspaper
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Vivendi SA's (12777.FR) Universal Music, the world's largest music publisher, is to experiment with selling digital music without copy protection, The Times in London reported Saturday.   According to The Times, Universal wants to see if the drawbacks associated with selling music without "digital rights management" or DRM protection are outweighed by the financial rewards.   The disclosure comes two months after EMI Group PLC (EMI.LN) announced it would make its music available without software-based anti-piracy protection.   The Times said rivals such as the second-ranked SonyBMG acknowledge that if the market leader changes its stance, neither it nor fourth-ranked Warner Music Group Corp. (WMG) will be able to persist with the same digital safeguards.   According to the newspaper the issue remains contentious even inside Universal, with some executives already testing the sale of music without copy protection, while others remain far more cautious.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9259     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 13:25 ET (17:25 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: HK Geely Auto May Sales Up 3.2% On Yr To 15,649 Units
Story: HONG KONG (Dow Jones)--Chinese automaker Geely Automobile Holdings Ltd. (0175.HK) said late Friday its May sales rose 3.2% from a year earlier, down from a 12% on-year rise in the previous month.   The Zhejiang province-based manufacturer, which makes and sells autos through affiliates in China, said it sold 15,649 autos in May. It didn't provide year-earlier figures.   The sales figure for May was lower than the 16,066 cars sold in April.   In the first five months of 2007, the company sold 82,850 cars, up 6.3% from the same period last year.   The January-May sales volume represented 34.5% of the total annual sales volume target of 240,000 units. Geely said it remains confident that its sales growth would speed up in the rest of the year, helped by a marketing campaign and new production capacity in China and abroad.     -By Jeffrey Ng, Dow Jones Newswires; 852-2802-7002; jeffrey.ng@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 05:06 ET (09:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: NYC Jeweler Accused Of Manipulating EBay Auctions
Story: NEW YORK (AP)--A Manhattan company that auctioned thousands of pieces of jewelry on eBay (EBAY) and other Web sites bamboozled customers by engaging in an illegal practice called shill bidding, New York's attorney general said.   Authorities announced Saturday that the company, EMH Group LLC, has agreed to pay $400,000 to settle charges that it inflated prices by bidding in its own auctions.   EMH, which did business under the name Jewelry by Ezra, and also operated its own site, www.auctionriot.com, will also be banned from the online auction business for four years.   The jeweler was accused of manipulating Internet auctions by instructing its employees to secretly bid on the items the company was selling, thereby driving up the price.   People trying to buy jewelry never realized that they were locked in a bidding war with competitors who didn't exist.   State officials said more than 232,000 of these shill bids were made over the course of a year, inflating prices by about 20%.   The company's owner, Ezra Dweck, did not return a phone message left at the company's Manhattan headquarters.   The case was brought to the state's attention by eBay's internal fraud investigation team.   "We do not tolerate criminal activity and proactively assist law enforcement to prosecute any individual who may try to defraud our users," eBay spokesman Nichola Sharpe said in a written statement.   Some consumers have criticized eBay for not doing enough to halt shill bidding.   Attorney General Andrew Cuomo said the case highlights "the growing vulnerability of online auction shoppers."     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 12:14 ET (16:14 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: GlaxoSmithKline Says Revolade Shows Benefit In ITP Patients
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--GlaxoSmithKline PLC (GSK), the world's second-largest pharmaceutical company, said Saturday its experimental drug Revolade can benefit patients with chronic idiopathic thrombocytopenia purpura, or ITP - a bleeding disorder in which the blood does not clot as it should.   The drug, taken as a pill, boosts the levels of blood platelets responsible for proper blood clotting.   According to data from a late-stage trial on 114 patients, once-daily treatment with Revolade significantly increased blood platelet counts and reduced bleeding in patients who had previously failed with other therapies for their condition.   The data, which are part of a six-week study, were presented at a European Hematology Association meeting in Vienna.   Known generically as eltrombopag, the drug is expected to be launched as Revolade in Europe and as Promacta in the U.S.   Analysts have estimated the product, which has also shown promising efficacy on hepatitis C patients in mid-stage clinical trials, could have a market opportunity of around $3 billion after it is launched.   There are estimated to be between 50,000 and 100,000 people with chronic ITP in the U.S.   Patients suffering from this condition, whose cause is currently unknown, often bleed from small blood vessels causing bruises, nosebleeds, bleeding from the gums during dental work, or other bleeding that is difficult to stop.   Other forms of thrombocytopenia occur as a result of chemotherapy treatment, viral infection or chronic liver disease.     Company Web site: http://www.gsk.com     -By Elena Berton, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 20 7842 9267; elena.berton@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 03:00 ET (07:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/11) Streetwise: The 5% Dilemma
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Michael Santoli   The "I remember when" crowd was incredulous last week that 10-year Treasury yields climbing above 5% could unnerve the stock market enough to prompt a 3% three-day drop from Tuesday through Thursday.   In the same tone parents used to tell of having had to milk the cows before breakfast in the days before fairies paid five bucks for a lost tooth, plenty of Wall Street voices insisted that 5.12% yields are "still low" and that stocks in the mid-'90s happily rallied with yields above 6%. To say nothing of the mid-teens rates near the dawn of the great bull market in 1982.   That's all true, of course, but somewhat beside the point. Because what matters is less where we are or where we've been than where we're headed. When yields were approaching the same levels above 5% in, say, 1993 and 1995 and 1998, it was on their way down in the grandest of all bond bull markets, one that lasted 20-plus years and culminated with Treasuries carrying a "3" handle a few years ago. This was a massive secular tailwind for stocks and gave upward impetus to equity valuations.   If, as now seems likely, that epochal downtrend in rates is reversing -- in whatever halting and saw-toothed pattern it follows -- then the same 5%-ish level becomes a headwind.   As noted here in recent weeks, during this bull market of four-plus years, stock indexes have made essentially no upside progress in periods when the 10-year yield has been above 4.75% or so. Stock valuations and M&A deal premiums, in this context, will be crimped at lower rates than we became accustomed to in the prior decade.   Moving beyond the history lessons, though, there are some encouraging aspects of the markets' action that suggest that this pullback in stocks (partially reversed with Friday's rally) is probably not the Big One, so to speak.   First is the fact that rising rates, which went unnoticed for weeks, have now become overexposed as a news story and a focal point of market commentary. From the headline-commanding comments of Pimco's Bill Gross (risk of 6.5% 10-years within five years) to the popular insistence that higher rates, at last, will bring the buyout boom to its Waterloo, this cacophony hints that stocks are in the process of discounting this story.   The other key sub-surface element to the bond selloff is that it wasn't accompanied by accelerating inflation expectations or carnage in the corporate-bond arena. Market-implied inflation forecasts have remained tame, and corporate-bond yields haven't risen nearly as fast as Treasuries. Corporate-bond spreads still seem too tight to the naked eye, but they have been a good indicator of general economic risk and liquidity for stocks.   Of course, part of this process of stocks' possibly making their peace with 5%-plus rates could well be continued weakness for a few more percent of downside. The first furious one-day rebound, such as Friday's, after such a brutal bout of selling as we saw last week usually can't be fully trusted.   Bulls, in fact, should be hoping this pullback gets deeper and generates a bit more fear than we've seen so far and quiets the chorus of those calling this a "buying opportunity." If the decline is undone in a hurry and a summer melt-up resumes, then we'd again have to start invoking those pesky 1987 analogies.   In the easy-money, deal-a-minute ethos of the present market, outsized attention is being paid to quick catalysts that create an instant one-time step increase in values -- LBOs, leveraged recapitalizations, corporate split-ups, huge stock buybacks.   Ignored, by contrast, are genuine organic-growth stories, companies that seem able to keep increasing earnings even as the profit cycle matures and slows.   Apple (AAPL) and Google (GOOG) are the two biggest exceptions to this rule. All the growth seekers are crowded into these two cult names and a few others.   It's telling that aggressive-growth mutual funds have seen net outflows for 12 consecutive months, totaling $43 billion, according to Citigroup. And the Russell 1000 Growth (IWF) exchange-traded fund has only $9.1 billion in assets, just two-thirds as much as its Russell 1000 Value ETF (IWD) counterpart.   Within sectors, there's very little valuation differentiation between companies with better and worse growth prospects. This spells opportunity, at least for relative returns. Morgan Stanley strategists have a "mispriced growth" screen that gets at stocks with better growth prospects than the market is crediting. This basket has performed well, and currently contains such names as ConocoPhilips (COP), WellPoint (WLP), Prudential (PRU), Altria (MO) and PNC Financial Services (PNC).   ---   e-mail: michael.santoli@barrons.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/11) Hard Times Ahead At The Mall
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Sandra Ward   Interview With Shawn Kravetz   Founder and president, Esplanade Capital     By sticking to select sectors and to disciplined investing principles, the man in charge of Boston-based Esplanade Capital has consistently rewarded investors with good ideas and strong performance. This year, Kravetz has delivered 9.45%, after fees, through May, and his fund has gained 16.57% a year on average, after fees, for the past five years. For the first time we can remember, he's not finding much to like in retailing, a specialty of his. But he's warmed upto the hot solar sector.     Barron's: Let's talk about your views on the retail sector.   Kravetz: Retail has always figured quite prominently in our portfolios. But today we have our lowest retail exposure in over five years, because there is an unfortunate confluence of growing risk as the stocks are rising and rarely does this lead to good investment opportunities, at least the way we think about them. We are just not finding much.     Q: Aren't there a lot of turnarounds to get interested in?   A: The markets tend to get very excited about the next big turnaround like the Gap [ticker: GPS], which had a lot of excitement around it during the holidays. But the excitement was on Wall Street, not in the stores. Paying high multiples for the promise of a turnaround or dramatic growth becomes a riskier and riskier bet as the environment gets tougher. We are cautious. We are thinking in terms of consumer compression not consumer recession.     Q: Meaning?   A: Meaning we expect a slowdown, as opposed to a collapse. A lot of my concern boils down more broadly to rates. If interest rates remain in this ballpark,  lots and lots of things will squeak by. But if we see a rate spike, the real-estate market will face even more risk, and that will have a substantial impact on consumption. People's discretionary income will fall dramatically as the cost of keeping a roof over their head rises. Lastly -- and this is very important -- the discount rate that we as investors use, and particularly what private-equity firms use to calculate their beloved terminal value -- the present value of future cash flows -- will go up, and the terminal value will fall. The private-equity put that has been so valuable of late across industries will start to wither. And the leverage that private-equity firms and  hedge funds use to support some of these valuations will also go away. A lot hinges on what happens with rates, and we don't see any immediate spike in rates. But that's the one thing that most concerns us.     Q: What retailers do you like?   A: In our entire universe, we could find only one core retail holding, and that's Tween Brands [TWB].     Q: Go on.   A: Tween Brands was formerly known as Too. But they changed their corporate name to reflect the fact that they have two very different distinctive retail banners today: the Limited Too, which is a great business, and a relatively new concept by the name of Justice. Limited Too is the most unheralded specialty-retailer growth story out there. They sell fantastically well-merchandised apparel and lifestyle products to girls between the ages of 7 and 14. It's a very steady, very profitable business with 570 stores and modest growth potential. Until recently, people thought they had no growth potential. But we think they'll increase square footage by 5% in the next couple of years. That's not immaterial. Combine that with 20%-plus operating profits at the store level, and this is just a great cash cow.   Justice, on the other hand, is the strip-mall version of Limited Too: You get a similar feeling but lower prices and the strip-mall format, which doubles their opportunity for square footage and market penetration. They have opened 184 stores under the Justice concept, and same-store sales comparisons were up 22% in its most recent quarter.     Q: Why is the stock underappreciated?   A: Only recently has Justice started to contribute to profits, because it was very small and there was some overhead required to open 184 stores. They are building 100 stores this year. Management thinks profit margins at Justice can be at least as high if not higher than the Limited Too margins. We agree with that because even though the average selling price is lower and gross margins are lower, the real estate is so much cheaper the operating margins can be higher. This is a business that in, say, 2008 can contribute roughly half as much to corporate profitability as the Limited Too division does. That's a big number for a piece of the puzzle that people still aren't talking much about yet.     Q: What are you expecting for earnings?   A: They are extremely well set up for the second half and, more importantly, 2008, when Justice will really be firing on all cylinders. Tween earned $1.95 a share last year. The company is guiding to $2.15 to $2.25 a share this year. But the story for us is 2008, and it is not unthinkable that they could earn $3 a share next year, up from $2.15 to $2.25 a share. They are also starting to do a virtual leveraged buyout. In the first quarter, they bought back $59 million worth of stock, or almost 5% of the company. You could easily see an 18 to 20 multiple that, if not in '08 then by '09, gets you to a $54 to $60 stock.     Q: What other sectors appeal to you?   A: We have been active in solar power. About three years ago, we started to see just a dramatic growth in the sector outside the U.S., and we started to appreciate the economics of solar power in a world very concerned with energy prices, energy independence and all things green. The solar market grew roughly 50% last year, and we believe it will grow 50% again this year. Growth would be faster if not for the global shortage of a key raw material, polysilicon, which is keeping prices higher and supply lower than normal. We see that situation easing in the coming couple of years. We see staggering growth. We see superb companies, and we see local and national governments around the world with a tremendous appetite for solar energy.     Q: How about a pick?   A: Evergreen Solar [ESLR]. It's in many ways the most interesting because it is the messiest story. They offer a very special technology called String Ribbon wafer technology that allows manufacturers of solar products to use less silicon, which is important given the shortage of silicon. Evergreen's technology uses about five grams of polysilicon to produce one watt of power and we think that will go to about three grams a watt by 2010. The industry average is closer to nine grams per watt.   Today, at a weighted average cost of $100 per kilogram of polysilicon, Evergreen spends about 50 cents a watt on silicon, and that's 30% of the total cost of the solar cell. A typical industry player would spend about a $1 per watt on silicon, representing almost 45% of the cost of goods sold. Evergreen has a 20% cost advantage. Even if silicon prices were cut in half, Evergreen would spend about 15 cents a watt on silicon, whereas an industry player would spend roughly twice that.     Q: What else does it have going for it?   A: Today versus last year at this time they have a terrific new CFO, their Ever Q joint venture with Q-Cells of Germany is humming, and they have a secured silicon supply.   They've raised a lot of money, and solar is on fire. And we see a company that is poised for tremendous growth over the next three to five years but whose stock, unlike many of its solar peers, has done nothing.     Q: How is that?   A: They do not make money today. They have had to raise a fair amount of capital to build plants. Historically, they have had poor Wall Street relations. Expectations, because of that, are quite low.     Q: Would they also be a takeover target at some point?   A: To us there are three potential outcomes to this story: One is what they are pursuing now, a go-it-alone strategy with some joint ventures where they can earn north of $1 a share by around 2010, and that gets you to a $15-$25 stock price. A second scenario, which I refer to as an "asset lite" strategy, is one where they become a technology-licensing company and instead of raising capital and building plants, license their technology for royalties.   That's not unlike what they've done with their joint venture in Germany, where they get a technology royalty, a marketing commission and also own a third of the equity. If they just went to a straight licensing fee, you could easily envision a business that generates a couple of hundred million in revenues at nearly 100% gross margins.   They could buy back stock. And you could see a stock that gets north of $20 a share based on $200 million or more in pure gross margin. The last scenario, which we think is incredibly viable, is the sale of the company.     Q: How about another idea?   A: Western Union [WU]. They are the leader in global money transfer, providing people around the world with easy and trustworthy ways to send money. They have 300,000 agent locations in 200 countries. It provides an absolutely vital service. We think it is underappreciated because Wall Street has an Internet view of the world, which is, why not use PayPal and credit cards to send money? But a lot of Western Union customers don't have access to e-mail or a computer or a bank, for that matter. When they were preparing to be spun out by First Data, we were astonished at their returns on capital, their cash-flow generation, their 30% profit margins. Historically, this has been a very solid and a low-double-digit-growth business. Nice and boring and immensely profitable. But because of the costs of becoming a public company and some short-term disruption in the Mexican market, an important market for them, and some headline risk on immigration reform, we think the stock now presents an opportunity.   Trading at just over 17 times 2008 earnings and just over 11 times 2008 Ebitda [earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization], it is just too cheap.     Q: Anything else?   A: We are short Amazon.com [AMZN].     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/11) European Trader: Patience Needed On Vodafone
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Arindam Nag   Shareholder activism is usually welcome, but not when the activists haven't done their homework. And in their present form, the suggestions made by a diverse group of Vodafone investors simply don't cut the mustard.   Efficient Capital Structures, formed specially to push for a restructuring of Vodafone, is suggesting the U.K. mobile operator issue a tracking stock that would reflect the value of its 45% investment in Verizon Wireless. It also wants Vodafone, whose American depositary receipts trade on the Big Board under the ticker symbol VOD, to leverage its balance sheet via a bond issue and to seek shareholders' permission before making any large acquisitions.   Spinning off the Verizon Wireless stake and issuing a tracking stock for it sounds good on paper. But it wouldn't be easy, simply because Vodafone doesn't control Verizon Wireless; Verizon Communications (VZ) owns the other 55% of the U.S. wireless outfit. A tracking stock normally is issued only when a parent company is in full control of a division. It's usually done with fast-growth divisions, allowing parent-company investors to assess their market value. AT&T issued one some years ago to track its wireless business. Genzyme did the same with its Celera Genomics unit.   If, as Efficient Capital suggests, Verizon Wireless were to issue a tracking stock listed in London, the value would only be in its dividend yield. It would have nominal voting rights, too few to influence operations -- which means it wouldn't carry a potential takeover premium. That would keep the tracking stock trading in a narrow range.   That said, Vodafone investors are justified in seeking to extract value from the Verizon venture. Vodafone CEO Arun Sarin told investors recently that once Verizon Wireless' current $12 billion debt load falls to zero -- which he see happening in two years -- dividends will start to flow.   Sarin could pressure Verizon to consider a faster timetable for dividends. That's not impossible: Verizon Wireless' recent performance has been impressive and its capital spending is well within control. What Vodafone shouldn't do is sell its stake under pressure from the activists, because it should be able to get far more value for it in two or three years. Verizon's growth is likely to accelerate in the next few quarters, on the back of mobile data services, which generate higher revenue than voice. This segment is taking off.   The activist investors also want Vodafone to raise more than 30 billion British pounds from the debt markets, so that it can take shareholder-friendly steps, such as buying in stock or boosting its dividend. Vodafone does have a strong balance sheet -- it's rated Single A -- but it simply can't afford that much leverage. Its emerging-markets units in Turkey, South Africa and India are expanding and they require capital.   If Vodafone takes on a lot of debt to satisfy investors, its credit rating is likely to be downgraded. That would raise its future cost of capital, hurting further access to capital needs for capital expenditures.   Vodafone shares have done well in the past year -- the ADRs are up more than 50%, to a recent $31.53 -- and have outpaced their benchmarks. Agitating investors should be patient and let the company's strategic moves pay off.   ---   Arindam Nag is a contributor to The Skeptic, a Dow Jones Newswires column on which this European Trader is based.   ---                           DOW JONES GLOBAL INDEXES    Region/  Country     DJ Global          DJ Global           DJ Global     Point      Indexes,           Indexes,            Indexes,      Chg.    % Chg.
