Headline: Barron's(6/11) Hospitality Sweet
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Leslie P. Norton   Time-share operators used to have a terrible reputation, with developers pushing shoddy resorts and high-pressure salesmen flogging properties as they plied potential buyers with margaritas. Then the regulators moved in, giving buyers the right to cancel purchases when the margaritas wore off. Today the business is booming and boasts double-digit annual growth for most of the past two decades.   The biggest hospitality companies, from Marriott International (MAR) to Walt Disney (DIS), now sell time shares, but the largest player in the industry, and arguably the most obscure, is Parsippany, N.J.-based Wyndham Worldwide (WYN). Time shares account for 41% of Wyndham's cash flow, while a "vacation exchange," which gives 3.4 million "members" access to 60,000 properties in a hundred countries, contributes another 33%. Wyndham also franchises nearly 6,500 economy and mid-priced hotels, including Super 8, Days Inn, Travelodge and Howard Johnson. Those brands were part of scandal-bowed Cendant, which a year  and a half ago  bought the tonier Wyndham brand.   Wyndham was spun out by Cendant last August, coming public at about 32 a share. It now trades for 35 and change and has a market value of $6.5 billion, though some fans are betting it's worth closer to 60 a share. "It's new, underappreciated and underfollowed," says Walter Scully, an analyst at Putnam Investments, which loaded up on Wyndham shares late last year.   Skeptics note that the lower-priced hotel segment hasn't grown as fast as luxury lodging and that the lodging cycle is long in the tooth. Moreover, unlike other innkeepers, Wyndham's clients are leisure, not business, travelers. The company's typical time-share customer -- a 58-year-old with an $85,000 annual income -- seems uncomfortably stretched.   These concerns, plus the lack of Wall Street coverage, are evident in Wyndham's valuation. The company trades for 20 times trailing earnings, compared with Marriott, at 28 times, and Starwood Hotels & Resorts (HOT), at 24 times.   With earnings poised to show impressive growth, the stock looks surprisingly cheap. In May, Wyndham reported first-quarter profit had tripled, buoyed by an increase in room revenue, an acquisition and strong vacation-ownership demand. For the full year, the company boosted its earnings forecast to $1.98 to $2.17 a share, on revenue of $4.35 billion to $4.51 billion (compared with earnings of $1.70 a share in 2006 on revenue of $3.84 billion). Wyndham also announced plans to start paying a cash dividend of four cents a share in the third quarter, and has been buying back stock.   "Wyndham has been a show-me stock, especially as it relates to earnings," Goldman Sachs analyst Steve Kent wrote after the March-quarter report. "For the third time in a row they delivered strong quarterly results."     Stephen Holmes, Wyndham's chief, counters critics by noting that while two-thirds of time-share buyers finance their purchases, paying rates of 10% to 15%, the rates are fixed and default rates haven't jumped because the payments are relatively small. Wyndham's recent $600 million offering of notes backed by time-share receivables was "way oversubscribed," Holmes says.   The market's concerns have created an "exceptionally cheap" stock, says Amit Kapoor, a lodging analyst at Gabelli & Co. Kapoor calculates Wyndham's private-market value by applying a 12 multiple to 2007 cash flow and subtracting net debt. The result: 58 a share, or 65% more than the current price. "It's hard to ignore," Kapoor says.   Analysts typically have awarded Wyndham multiples of 12 times earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization for lodging; 10  to 11 times for vacation exchange, and seven  to eight times for the time-share unit. But Holmes argues the time-share valuation -- just a notch below a lodging multiple -- should be higher. In the past 15 years, he says, U.S. time-share-industry revenue has grown 14% a year, seemingly impervious to events like 9/11, and some 40% of Wyndham's new customers become repeat buyers.   Says Franz Hanning, chief of the time-share operation: "We're still at less than 5% penetration. If the ultimate [saturation] rate is 15%, we have 100 years left."   Wyndham has a flexible points-based system that attracts customers and a strong portfolio of destinations for drivers (Branson, Mo.; Myrtle Beach, S.C.) and fliers (Waikiki, Las Vegas). It is building time shares around hotels in Puerto Rico and Orlando, and rapidly expanding its high-end "Presidential" inventory. In the next five years, rebranding time shares under the Wyndham flag -- helped by a TV campaign featuring Arnold Palmer -- could also boost operating margins by 3.5 percentage points from a current 15%, Hanning says.   Wyndham also has aggressive plans to build its lodging business, adding 165,000 net rooms by 2010. And it is expanding rapidly around the world, including in India and China. The company's cheap stock also might draw the attention of buyout firms; takeover speculation has buzzed around Marriott, Starwood and Wyndham. At current multiples, there's plenty of room at the inn.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Investors Snub Vodafone Rebels -Newspaper
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--An activist shareholder group that wants to break up mobile phone operator Vodafone Group PLC (VOD) is struggling to win support, The Times in London reported Saturday.   Six key investors, including Morley Fund Management, Insight Investment Management and second-biggest shareholder M&G Investment Management, will vote against the radical proposals advocated by Efficient Capital Structures, the newspaper said.   The activist group led by former Marconi executive John Mayo has urged the Newbury, England-based operator to restructure debt and separate its Verizon Wireless joint venture.   According to The Times, Vodafone's former chairman Lord MacLaurin of Knebworth has described the plans as "ludicrous."   Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9259     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 12:52 ET (16:52 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: PepsiCo To Build $170 Mln Plant In Russia -Tass
Story: MOSCOW (Dow Jones)--U.S. soft drink and snack maker PepsiCo Inc. (PEP) Saturday signed an agreement with the government of the Rostov region in southern Russia to build a Frito Lay chips plant, news agency Prime-Tass reported.   Under the agreement, signed at the St. Petersburg Economic Forum, the company will invest $170 million in the plant in the next five years.   Pepsi currently has six plants in Russia and is building a seventh.     Agency Web site: http://www.prime-tass.ru     -By Moscow Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +7 495 974 8055     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 12:42 ET (16:42 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(6/11) Research Reports
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Anita Peltonen   The research reports excerpted here were issued recently by investment firms. Many may be obtained through Thomson Financial at www.thomson.com/financial or 800-638-8241. Some are available in the company-research area of WSJ.com, or through Factiva.com. Some of the reports' issuers have provided, or hope to provide, investment-banking or other services to the companies being analyzed.     California Water Service Group   -- CWT-NYSE     Hold - Price 37.48 on June 6   by Brean Murray Carret & Co.     The company entered into an unsecured credit agreement for a revolving line of credit for up to $75 million. Bank of America is providing the entire line, with $55 million of credit extended to [the company] and its subsidiaries, with another $20 million provided by an unsecured loan agreement. The company stated the credit lines would be used for general corporate purposes, working capital, capital expenditures and potential acquisitions.     Flextronics International   -- FLEX-NNM     Outperform - Price 11.70 on June 5   by Bear Stearns     FLEX will acquire [Solectron] SLR for about $3.6 billion in cash and stock. The combined company will have annual revenue of about $30 billion-plus and 200,000 employees, including 4,000 design engineers. Sony Ericsson will be the only customer above 10% of sales. We view this transaction positively for FLEX and could see [roughly] $2-to-$3 of value creation if its accretion targets are met. Maintaining Outperform and 15 target.     Harbin Electric   -- HRBN-NNM     Speculative Buy - Price 13.64 on June 7   by Dutton Associates     Target 16.02. Harbin Electric [recently] announced that . . . it has commenced shipment of customized motors for use in interior electric-seating applications for autos. Harbin is the sole supplier for this program . . . The Harbin Electric-built motor is part of a system that offers one-touch powered operation, which completely folds a seat in less than 15 seconds. The [system] also includes an obstacle-detection system that will stop the seat from folding in the event a person or object is in the way.     Kona Grill - KONA-NNM     Hold - Price 18.36 on June 7   by Wedbush Morgan     Target 18. KONA lowered 2007 unit-development guidance from six unit openings to four as the planned openings in Gilbert, Ariz., and West Palm Beach, Fla., are now expected in the first half of 2008 versus Q4 previously. Reducing our 2007 revenue estimate to $72.3 [million] from $73.2 million to reflect 13 fewer operating weeks, but raising our street-low 2007 EPS estimate from [a loss of 53 cents] to [a loss of 35 cents] on development delays resulting in lower pre-opening expenses . . . our 2008 revenue estimate decreases from $119.8 million to $112.3 million.       McDermott Int'l.   -- MDR-NYSE     Neutral - Price 80.87 on June 6   by W. Quillen Securities     We are downgrading McDermott [engineering and construction] to Neutral from Buy, as the stock at 80 nears our prior target of 83. Stock is now at 19 times our forward four-quarter estimates, and 12.1x on (forward) EV/Ebitda [enterprise value/earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization] . . . The best case yields a price/earnings ratio on 2008 of 16 times, and the worst case yields a PE on 2008 of 20 times.There are . . . global political risks that pushed us over the cliff in downgrading, especially with the Russian missile imbroglio.     Met-Pro   -- MPR-NYSE     Market Perform - Price 15.53 on June 7   Sturdivant & Co.     Met-Pro [a global product-recovery/pollution control/fluid-handling firm] is positioned for strong earnings . . . we believe it will earn 79 cents in FY08 and 85 cents in FY09 . . . driven by solid top-line growth due to strong momentum in end-markets . . . Gross margin should improve due to an optimization of the supply chain. [And] we expect recent cost-cutting initiatives to improve operating expenses . . . At this time the attractiveness of owning Met-Pro shares is reduced by the stock's current valuation in relation to its peer group.     Portfolio Recovery Associates   -- PRAA-NNM     Strong Buy - Price 55.19 on June 4   by JMP Research     We are raising our rating on Portfolio Recovery Associates . . . to Strong Buy, as we believe that the supply and pricing characteristics of the charged-off debt market are improving and that the company remains over-capitalized despite its recently announced $1 special dividend and 1 million share-repurchase program. We believe . . . the company may be entering another "sweet spot" in which . . . mid-teens to 20%-plus EPS growth looks achievable.   We are raising our 2007 EPS estimate from $3.23 to $3.24 and our 2008 estimate from $3.75 to $3.80 . . . Our 12-month target price is raised from 64 to 66 and equates to roughly 17 times our 2008 estimate, a slight discount to PRA's four-plus-year average forward multiple as a public company.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: US, Russian Business To Intensify WTO Entry Lobbying
Story: SAINT PETERSBURG (Dow Jones)--Russian and U.S. business leaders said Saturday they have formed a special working group to lobby their respective governments for a speedy accession of Russia to the World Trade Organization.   Alexei Mordashov, chief executive of steelmaker OAO Severstal (CHMF.RS), told reporters that Russian accession to the WTO is still technically possible this year, but "depends on the good will" of both sides.   He added that Russia's accession "is important not only for the Russian economy, but also for the success of foreign companies operating in Russia."   Chevron Corp. (CVX) chief executive David O'Reilly will co-chair the group with Mordashov. Chevron is the largest private shareholder in the Caspian Pipeline Consortium, which exports Kazakh oil from the Russian Black Sea port of Novorossisk. It has also expressed an interest in importing gas to the U.S. from the huge Shtokman project in the Barents Sea, being developed by gas monopoly OAO Gazprom (GSPBEX.RS).   A study by Ernst & Young commissioned by the U.S. Chamber of Commerce in Russia "proves that the Russian economy is an engine of growth for U.S. companies," the chamber's head in Russia, Andrew Somers, said at the same briefing.     -By Geoffrey T. Smith, Dow Jones Newswires; (+7 985) 103 1191; geoffrey.smith@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 03:13 ET (07:13 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/11) 13D Filings: Investors Report To The SEC
Story: (From BARRON'S)   13Ds are supposed to be filed within 10 days of an entity's attaining more than 5% of any class of a company's securities. Subsequent changes must be reported on amended filings. This material is from filings released by the SEC from May 31 through June 6.   Source: Dow Jones Corporate Filings Alert     Activists     Building Materials (BLG)   Hedge-fund manager Robert Chapman sent a letter to the company requesting a meeting with top management. Chapman said that he'd like to discuss Building Materials' expense-reduction and capital-allocation plans. Chapman also reiterated his request that Building Materials hire an investment adviser to explore the sale of the company.   Chapman Capital reported ownership of 2.4 million shares (8.1% of the total outstanding).     ESS Technology (ESST)   Riley Investment Management said that the company should shut its operations, sell its assets and return the proceeds to shareholders. Riley Investment contends that this would generate proceeds of $2.70 a share and warned that, otherwise, the company has "little or no prospect of turning a profit in the foreseeable future." Riley Investment asserts that the management of ESS faces an "uphill battle" in restoring profitability to the company, citing intense competition and what it termed a declining outlook for ESS' core DVD-chip products.   Riley Investment owns 6.7% of the shares outstanding.     PVF Capital (PVFC)   Investor Umberto P. Fedeli submitted a proposal asking the company to declassify its board structure. Fedeli said that he would buy 1.5 million to two million shares if he were allowed to control three board seats and if the company shook up its management and altered its strategic business plan. The company hasn't issued an official response to Fedeli's offer.   The declassification proposal would require that all PVF directors be elected each year, instead of having only a few directors up for annual election. Fedeli currently holds 465,000 shares (6%).     Original Filings     INX (INXI)   Doucet Capital reported ownership of 348,279 shares (5.3%) after buying 6,845 from May 4 to 30 at prices ranging from $9.25 to $10.98. INX provides Internet protocol communications services and products.     Increases in Holdings     Advanced Medical Optics (EYE)   A group including ValueAct Capital Management raised its stake to 5.9 million shares (9.9%) from the 4.4 million (7.3%) reported on May 1. Advanced Medical Optics makes eye-care and ophthalmologic devices.     Reuters Group (RTRSY)   ValueAct Capital Management raised its holdings to 96.4 million shares (7.7%) from the 83.55 million (6.5%) that it reported on Feb. 21.     Halozyme Therapeutics (HALO)   Halozyme director Randal J. Kirk increased his stake to 11.04 million shares (14.6%) from the 7.5 million (10.5%) that he reported on May 24. Halozyme is a biopharmaceutcial company based in San Diego.     Decreases in Holdings     Casual Male Retail Group (CMRG)   Jewelcor Management reduced its holdings to 4.1 million shares (12.5%) from the 5.62 million (16.3%) reported last December.     Capella Education (CPLA)   Technology Crossover Management V cut its holdings to 1.57 million shares (9.4%) from the 1.96 million (12.3%) reported in November 2006.     Design Within Reach (DWRI)   Glenhill Advisors cut its position to 2.1 million shares (14.7%) from the 2.5 million (17.4%) reported in May 2006. Design Within Reach markets furniture and other products.     EGL (EAGL)   SuttonBrook Capital Management lowered its stake to 722,600 shares (1.77%) from the 2.19 million (5.37%) reported in mid-May.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/11) Speaking Of Dividends: Paper Profit
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Shirley A. Lazo   One of the nation's leading book retailers, Books-A-Million, told an interesting dividend story last week.   The No. 3 chain (after Barnes & Noble and Borders) Wednesday declared a one-time payout of $3 a share. That's worth some $50.4 million to the Birmingham, Ala., company's investors. The stock, which changes hands on Nasdaq, surged 6% that day in after-hours trading and Friday was at 18.58. It's 52-week  high and low are 23.70 and 13.77.   The bonus dividendispayable July 5 to holders of record June 20. The ex-date is June 18.   Founded in 1917 as a street-corner newsstand, Books-A-Million (ticker: BAMM) initiated quarterly dividends in August 2004 at the rate of three cents a share. Its latest boost, to nine cents, came in March, and the stock currently yields 1.94%. Barnes & Noble (BKS) pays 15 cents  a share quarterly and   trades in the low 40s, while Borders (BGP) disburses 11 cents and changes hands around 20. Chairman Clyde B. Anderson and his family own approximately 48% of Books-A-Million's 16.8 million outstanding shares.   Oprah Winfrey's endorsement of Rhonda Byrne's self-help book, The Secret, helped results in the company's first fiscal quarter (ended April 30), as did better fiction sales. Profits surged 40% from the level a year earlier, to $2.1 million, or 13 cents a share, on a 2% gain in volume, to $116.3 million. Publication of the seventh and final Harry Potter book on July 21 should make Books-A-Million's second fiscal quarter read well.     A world leader in industrial packaging products and services, Greif (GEF) Monday enhanced its quarterly common payout on its nonvoting Class A stock a hefty 56%, to 28 cents a share from 18 cents. Ditto its Class B stock,   to 42 cents from 27 cents. The numbers are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in April.   Chief Executive Michael J. Gasser called the boost "consistent with the company's targeted dividend payout ratio of 30% to 35% over a complete business cycle." Shareholders of record June 18 will receive the new disbursements July 1; the ex-dividend date is June 14.   The 130-year-old Greif (rhymes with "life"), which is headquartered in Delaware, Ohio, has paid dividends without interruption since 1926. This is the fourth consecutive annual increase and the third of at least 50%. The Class A shares, listed on the Big Board, are  trading 13% under their 52-week high of 63.97. Yield: 2.02%.     A component of the Dow Jones transports, Overseas Shipholding Group (OSG) hiked its quarterly common payout 25% Wednesday, to 31.25 cents a share from 25 cents. The respective payment, record and ex dates are Aug. 28, Aug. 7 and Aug. 3. Yield: 1.69%. Dividends have been ongoing since 1973. This is the second consecutive annual boost. The stock is 9% below  its 52-week high of 80.77.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 00:09 ET (04:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: US Sen Clinton: Pair Auto Fuel Econ Gains With Cost Relief
Story: By John D. Stoll     OF DOW JONES NEWSWIRES     DETROIT (Dow Jones)--U.S. Sen. Hillary Clinton on Saturday took a softer approach compared to her top rival for the 2008 Democratic nomination in addressing the problems ailing domestic car companies as she insisted there needs to be a "win-win" solution for Detroit auto makers.   In a speech to the AFL-CIO union in Michigan, the Democratic presidential contender said she believes "we have got to do something to raise gas mileage," but insisted higher requirements need to be accompanied with federal relief on health-care costs.   "I believe we need to do more to support the American auto makers," Clinton, of New York, said. She said the ongoing debate over the congressional push to increase so-called corporate average fuel economy requirements, or CAFE, presents "a very tough question."   Clinton's suggestion that fuel-economy improvements by Ford Motor Co. (F), General Motors Corp. (GM) and DaimlerChrysler AG's (DCX) Chrysler Group should be incentivized by health-care relief echoes a plan initiated last month by rival Sen. Barack Obama of Illinois. But, she struck a more conciliatory tone.   Obama last month came to the Motor City and criticized  Detroit auto makers for being slow in creating more fuel-efficient cars and trucks. He criticized Detroit executives for lobbying against legislation that would force auto makers to meet higher standards.   Detroit auto makers currently pay out about $12 billion in health care costs annually, and long-term legacy obligations to retirees are widely seen as the single-biggest risk auto makers face and some analysts suggest at least one auto maker could fail if costs aren't addressed. At GM, where obligations are the biggest, the company funds health-care for three retirees for every one active employee.   Although two major Democratic candidates are now suggesting fuel-economy gains should be incentivized by cost relief, it is unclear if the agenda will extract support from U.S. auto makers that have typically supported Republican candidates with the majority of donations and other support.   Nevertheless, Clinton's softer approach may heal some of the wounds Obama may have opened last month among industry leaders. In a speech following Obama's remarks, Ford Chairman Bill Ford characterized Obama as being misguided and invited him to tour the company's plant in Chicago.   Unlike Obama, who anchored a Detroit Economic Club speech with his criticism, Clinton didn't specifically put forth a plan for Detroit in terms of fuel economy and health care. She made the suggestion at the end of a question and answer session. Her speech was largely devoted to previously-proposed initiatives.   Clinton's comments come following a week during which the vehicle fuel-economy debate was in the national spotlight.   On Wednesday, the chief executives of the so-called Big Three domestic auto makers visited several congressional leaders in an effort to lobby lawmakers as they consider boosting fuel-economy requirements for auto makers. Congressional Democrats are pushing a plan that would force car companies to raise fuel-economy standards - known as "CAFE" - to 35 miles per gallon by 2020, up from a range of 22.5 to 27.5 miles per gallon currently in place. During a speech Tuesday, General Motors Corp. (GM) Chief Executive Rick Wagoner characterized CAFE as ineffective and called for a more proactive approach to energy diversification.   In prepared remarks to congressional leaders, Wagoner said the U.S. auto makers don't enjoy the same subsidies that Japanese auto makers do. He referenced a recent decision by Japan's government to commit to billions of dollars in funding for Japanese companies trying to create alternative fuel technologies. Wagoner, who says he expects to see higher CAFE standards coming from congress, asked for similar support to what Japanese auto makers enjoy.   During her speech, Clinton referenced a proposal that could begin to address Wagoner's concerns. She said she is in favor of creating a $50 million "strategic energy fund" that would be paid for by canceling tax subsidies handed out to oil companies.   Clinton  said the U.S. government needs to ramp up funding for energy projects that would lessen dependence of foreign oil. She said the U.S. needs an energy program that is on par with the Apollo space program initiated in the 1960s to fund space exploration.   Clinton noted that Japan provides funding for energy technologies. But Clinton's current proposal calls for only a relatively modest $50 million energy fund, which likely would fall far short of Detroit's needs in the fuel-economy race. She has suggested making permanent research-and-development tax credits that currently are renewed periodically.   By taking on tax subsidies to oil companies, Clinton is pitting a richly-profitable industry against the ailing auto industry. Auto maker executives have repeatedly called on government to push other industries to help finding a solution to energy concerns.   During the speech and a question and answer session, Clinton touched on several issues pressuring the Big Three. She said she would be "tougher" and "smarter" on addresses trade pacts that bar U.S. auto makers from key markets, including South Korea. She consistently acknowledged that there are several issues squeezing Detroit and insisted that tackling those issues would be a top priority if she is elected president next year.   -By John D. Stoll, Dow Jones Newswires; 248-204-5533; john.stoll@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 13:48 ET (17:48 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/11) Tech Trader: Key Query For Internet Dealmakers: Author, Author?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Eric J. Savitz   It all seems so logical.   In recent weeks, the Internet sector has been picked nearly clean of independent online advertising and marketing firms. Google (ticker: GOOG) triggered the shopping spree in mid-April with its $3.1 billion deal to buy DoubleClick. Two weeks after that, Yahoo! (YHOO) agreed to buy the 80% of Right Media it didn't already own for $680 million. In mid-May, the advertising giant WPP Group (WPPGY) inked a $649 million agreement to buy 24/7 Real Media (TFSM). And that was followed almost immediately by Microsoft's (MSFT) announcement of its biggest deal ever, a $6 billion acquisition of aQuantive (AQNT).   More than $10 billion later, with just one decent-sized independent online ad player left -- ValueClick (VCLK), which I'll come back to in a bit -- the stock market in its infinite wisdom has decided that the obvious next move would be consolidation of the Internet content business. Seems logical. If the Internet advertising sector is going to be big enough to create a feeding frenzy among the companies serving up the ads, then you'd think it should be boom times for the content players.   Ergo, time to shop for content stocks . . . right? Well, not necessarily.   Certainly, it isn't hard to come with a list of potential targets. CNET (CNET), a subject of recurring takeover rumors, is the company to buy for tech news and reviews. WebMD (WBMD) offers one of the few sources of premium content on health-related topics. BankRate (RATE) offers info on mortgages and other loans. There's TheStreet.com (TSCM), for stock information. The Knot (KNOT), for wedding-related information. Answers.com (ANSW), for, well, answers to your every question. For the ultra speculative crowd, you can bet on micro-caps like PlanetOut (LGBT) and Quepasa (QPSA).   What I've been wondering is: Why haven't any of these companies been bought so far?   There's no single reason, but I have a general theory. Problem  No. 1: None of the key buyers in the recent ad-firm consolidation -- Google, Yahoo! and Microsoft -- ap-pear all that interested in owning companies that pay people to create content.   And that leads us to Problem No. 2. What those companies -- and their counterparts in the mainstream media -- actually are interested in is user-generated content. They're enamored of social networks, places where users will return over and over again to entertain and socialize with each other. We have met the content, and it is us.   Ergo, Google paid $1.65 billion for YouTube. Just a few days ago, rumors resurfaced that Yahoo! might make a run at the social networking site FaceBook. News Corp. (NWS) -- which may or may not end up owning Dow Jones, publisher of this magazine -- two years ago spent $580 million for MySpace, in what was almost certainly one of the bargains of the century; its value likely has gone up 10-fold or more. More recently, it bought photo-sharing site Photobucket. CBS in recent weeks has acquired the cutesy stock-market Web video site WallStrip, as well as the Internet radio provider Last.fm; those two provide more traditional content, video and music, but they do it the Internet way: on the cheap.   Meanwhile, we get to Problem No. 3. The barriers to creating compelling content on the Web are falling rapidly. CNET, for instance, faces challenges from a host of all-purpose gadget blogs, like Engadget and Gizmodo, and more specialized sites like Digital Photography Review, which by the way was recently acquired by Amazon.com (AMZN). Content is spreading into the long tail; the niche markets aren't that niche-y any more.   What buyers want, in other words, is not paid-content creators (i.e., people like me); they want content-creation tools that consumers (i.e., people like you) can use to produce their own content. It's about photo-sharing and networking and video creation, and blogs and podcasts and wikis. Paid writers and editors creating content? How Web 1.0.   I'm not actually convinced that very many of those Web content companies I mentioned earlier are going to be acquired anytime soon. WebMD has a nice niche, but trades for 100-times 2007 earnings estimates; hard to imagine how much higher a bidder could go. I've never believed in the CNET rumors; I think there is simply too much competition for the tech advertising dollar for it to maintain an advantage over more niche-oriented tech sites. The Street.com does good journalism, but remains so closely tied to Jim Cramer that it is hard to know what it might really be worth. PlanetOut is in financial crisis and could end up insolvent. Quepasa is a micro-cap turnaround story. Answers.com has been trading wildly and generates scant revenue. My colleague Tiernan Ray makes the case for BankRate and The Knot in a story posted last week on Barrons.com ("Tasty Internet Acquisition Targets," June 6); but even there I am skeptical that the shares are cheap enough to lure a buyer.   Speaking at a conference in Santa Clara, California last week, Cisco Systems' (CSCO) Dan Scheinman, vice president and general manager of the company's media solutions group, asserted that "community" over the next few years will become a better source of information for many people than search engines. And therein lies the problem for the Web content companies: Professionally produced content is yesterday's story. The growth is in social networks and community.   In a report  Thursday, Spencer Wang, an analyst at Bear Stearns, noted that traffic to just six sites with user-generated content -- Myspace.com, Facebook.com, Youtube.com, Wikipedia.org, Blogger.com and Digg.com -- accounted for 13% of U.S. Internet traffic in April, up from 7% a year earlier, and a mere 0%-1% as recently as 2004. That's where the action is.   A final point. Stock activity doesn't necessarily mean an actual takeover bid is coming. ValueClick shares gyrated wildly after Microsoft announced its deal with aQuantive, as investors more or less ignored a potentially highly damaging FTC investigation into the company's lead-generation business. Last week, there was speculation about the possible sale of Monster.com (MNST), which has gone through a complete management overhaul, and Netflix.com (NFLX), which was rumored a potential target for Amazon. Again, I'm not sure that any of those companies is going to actually be acquired at current prices. What you really want to buy are sites like FaceBook and Digg and MySpace; alas, you can't.   ---   E-mail: eric.savitz@barrons.com   ---   Infield Talent Switch     WHEN BILL ALPERT started his Tech Trader column for Barron's five years ago, the Nasdaq was half its current level and technology stocks were seriously out of favor. Why start a technology investing column after the bubble had burst? Because we were convinced that tech investing from 2002 onward would be different than it was in the indiscriminate mania of the 1990s. We felt that this time around, lots of tech companies would come roaring back while many others would go belly up. We were dead right, just as Bill has been on so many of his predictions. His 2006 calls had a return of 14%, versus a 9% gain for the Nasdaq. No wonder his column has become one of the magazine's most popular.   But now Bill is moving on to other duties, specifically writing trenchant feature stories and cover stories about overvalued and undervalued companies. He'll also be using one of his special skills: warning readers about scams in the market. We thank Bill for giving life to the Tech Trader column and turning it into such a success. We look forward to reading his stories in the months ahead.     SUCCEEDING BILL AS TECH TRADER     Columnist is Eric Savitz, a veteran Barron's West Coast editor who one year ago started Tech Trader Daily, his outstanding blog on Barron's Online (www.barrons.com). In the past 12 months, Eric has posted more than 3,000 items, covering every development that matters to technology investors. Eric was way ahead of the competition on predicting Vonage's crumbling stock price, the slowdown in the chip and disk-drive sector, and the consolidation of Internet advertising companies. Besides writing the Tech Trader column in print, Eric will continue to pen his blog.   And don't forget our other terrific online commentators, including Barron's Online Editor Randall Forsyth, who writes Up and Down Wall Street Daily. Randy alerted his readers to the growing impact of foreign governments' direct investments in global capital markets three months before China's ground-breaking announcement of a $3 billion stake in the private-equity giant Blackstone.   Options Editor Steven Sears authors Striking Price Daily, the best options column in the business. Example: Steve saw value in selling Johnson & Johnson put options in mid-May to take advantage of overly negative investor sentiment, just before it was revealed that Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway had doubled its holding in the health-care company. The gain for readers who took Steve's advice: 30%.   For now at least, you can read the work of Eric, Steve and Randy without charge because their columns reside on a free portion of Barron's Online. Do your portfolio a favor: Check them out.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/11) Commodities Corner: Zinc Price In A Vise
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Lisa Yuriko Thomas   The mining industry has seen a rush of mergers and acquisitions over the past few years -- but zinc has missed out on the frenzy.   That could now change, as high prices have made the splintered zinc industry a tantalizing target for consolidation. Since mid-2005, the metal's price has soared some 200%, to around $3,600 a metric ton, due to dwindling stockpiles and Chinese demand. In 2006, zinc was the second-best performer on the London Metal Exchange, rising more than 120%.   "Most consolidation will lead to economies of scale, and increased [production] efficiencies in sectors such as marketing, technology and others -- and therefore apply downward pressure on costs," says Michael Foster, managing director of U.K.-based producer ZincOx.   The white metal is used to galvanize steel and prevent corrosion. Part of what makes zinc different from other metals is that deposits of the ore in which it is found are small and geologically scattered. As such, many players control only small bits of the world's zinc output, says George Pirie, president of Canada's Breakwater Resources (ticker: BWR.Canada) -- leaving no super player focused on the metal's production.   Teck merged with Cominco in 2001 to form Teck Cominco (TCK), which has the world's largest zinc mine in Alaska. More recently, Australian zinc producer Zinifex (ZFX.Australia) combined with Belgium's Umicore to create the world's biggest zinc producer.   That sounds impressive, but according to the industry's consensus estimate, the top 20 zinc companies control just over 50% of the world's refined production. In comparison, the top five nickel companies control 60% of global refined nickel production.   "The zinc industry being more fragmented certainly means less supply discipline from the producers . . . leading to fluctuating prices," says ZincOx's Foster.   Strength in metals prices across the board has encouraged an unprecedented wave of mergers and acquisitions over the past year, as the world's largest miners are under pressure to deliver consistent returns and to keep supply and demand in balance. And zinc players want in on the action. Brazilian metals producer Votorantim Metais -- the world's No. 5 zinc producer -- said in late May that it hopes to become a global player through expansion outside Latin America. Vancouver-based Lundin Mining (LMC) has also been active on the acquisition trail.   "A key to whether a company will engage in mergers and acquisitions is company management, and whether the board has the initiative to push for such activity," says Michael Cuoco, a metals research analyst with Mitsui Bussan Commodities in New York.   One major caveat: The market can be greatly influenced by China, which is both the largest producer and consumer of zinc. The question is: How much pricing power can be achieved without that nation's involvement? Yet China now looks ready to begin its own consolidation push. In response to surging production, the fractured nature of the business and hopes for sustainable development of the zinc industry, Beijing has pushed for reforms to curb capacity expansion and to restrict mining.   ---   Lisa Yuriko Thomas is a metals reporter for Dow Jones Newswires in London.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: GAZ Grp Signs Pact To Invest $443M In Regional Engine Plant
Story: MOSCOW (Dow Jones)--Russian car maker OAO GAZ Group (GAZA.RS) Saturday said it had signed an agreement to invest 11.5 billion rubles ($443 million) between 2007 and 2009 in upgrading its existing diesel engine plants in the Yaroslavl Region in central Russia.   The document, signed at a forum in St. Petersburg, followed an agreement at the end of March on social and economic partnership between GAZ and the Yaroslavl regional administration.   Company Web site: http://www.gaz.ru   -By Elena Murina, Dow Jones Newswires; +7 495 974 80 55; elena.murina@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 08:39 ET (12:39 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Harold McGraw III Urges Business Graduates to Take Action, Help Retain America's Position as Leader of the Global Economy
Story: Chairman, President and CEO of the McGraw-Hill Companies Delivers Commencement Address at Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth       NEW YORK, June 9 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Harold McGraw III, chairman, president and CEO of The McGraw-Hill Companies (NYSE: MHP), delivered today's commencement address at the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth.  In his address, Mr. McGraw spoke on the issue of American competitiveness in the global economy and the responsibility and authority that Tuck's graduates have as future business leaders of our country.     Encouraging students to keep their sites on America's role in the global marketplace, Mr. McGraw spoke of the country's status as a global leader in danger of losing its competitive edge:     "Your graduation is timely, desperately needed, and the business world awaits your leadership. Unlike no other time, America and American business faces a serious shortage of highly skilled talent, and at a time when our world is rapidly growing up, and 'transformational change' is influencing and affecting every business, every industry, every country. Our competitiveness is at stake."     Regarding the state of education in the U.S., Mr. McGraw continued, "Today the quality of education is the overriding domestic issue in our country. It's a major concern for the United States. It's a major issue for the business community. It is an issue that will preoccupy many of you as future business leaders. And the reason that it will preoccupy you is that - put bluntly - our nation faces a shortage of human capital."     Concluding, Mr. McGraw spoke about the responsibility of the business world and Tuck's graduating class toward ensuring that education in America remains a priority for all Americans.     "Those of us who are in the business community have a major obligation - call it self-interest if you wish - to make sure that our education system produces these vital human resources. As a nation we need to develop our human resources - our 'talent pool' - and reverse the declines in educational quantity and quality of the last few decades. As a business community, we need to support efforts in both the public and private sectors to equip our young people with the skills they need to compete in an increasingly demanding global environment. As individual corporate leaders we need to recognize that success resides not upon our own knowledge and wisdom but upon our ability to recruit, develop and empower an effective 'talent pool.' As executives we need to model the qualities that we require in our talent pool - including the willingness to capture new ideas wherever they come from."     Founded in 1900, the Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth was the nation's first graduate school of business and consistently ranks in the top 10 in all major business school rankings.        About The McGraw-Hill Companies:     Founded in 1888, The McGraw-Hill Companies is a leading global information services provider meeting worldwide needs in the financial services, education and business information markets through leading brands such as Standard & Poor's, McGraw-Hill Education, BusinessWeek and J.D. Power and Associates. The Corporation has more than 280 offices in 40 countries. Sales in 2006 were $6.3 billion. Additional information is available at http://www.mcgraw-hill.com.
