Headline: LSE Hits Electronic Trade Target A Year Early -FT
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--The London Stock Exchange Group PLC (LSE) has seen a surge in average trading volumes on its SETS electronic order book, hitting nearly 500,000 a day, the Financial Times in London reported Saturday.   That is comfortably ahead of the 2008 target date that the exchange had set for itself when it saw off a hostile bid from U.S. rival Nasdaq (NDAQ) this year, the newspaper said.   New, lower fees aimed at rewarding LSE customers with the highest trading volumes take effect this month as does a new, high-speed trading platform called TradeElect, the Financial Times added.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.ft.com   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9259     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 10:58 ET (14:58 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/11) High-Risk Realty
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrew Bary   The proposed leveraged buyout of Archstone-Smith, one of largest real-estate-investment trusts focused on apartments, is a prime example of the current mania for all types of income-producing property.   In late May, Archstone (ticker: ASN) agreed to be taken private for $22 billion by a group including Tishman Speyer, the privately held New York real-estate firm, and the real-estate investment arms of Lehman Brothers (LEH) and Bank of America (BAC). The buyout group is paying $60.75 a share for Archstone, or nearly $16 billion. The company also has $6 billion of debt. Archstone shares, which stood at $51 prior to the deal, traded at $60.50 on Friday as investors figured there might be a higher bid.   The Tishman-led buyout group isn't talking publicly, but the deal appears to be very aggressively structured in view of the debt that will be piled on the private company and amount of operating income produced by its properties.   Archstone owns a great collection of apartment buildings and complexes in such affluent areas as Southern California, the San Francisco region and Manhattan, where land is scarce and barriers to new construction are high. Yet the challenge for the buyers is that they are effectively getting a yield of just over 4% on the apartments -- one of the lowest returns in the entire REIT sector -- while the cost of financing the purchase is apt to top 6%. This means interest costs likely will exceed operating income, making the buyout a gigantic gamble.   The Archstone deal typifies the shift in the attitude of real-estate investors. Once focused on income, they now view office buildings, apartment complexes and shopping centers like stocks. They're willing to accept low initial yields in a bet that rents and property prices will keep rising. The risk lies in rising interest rates and tightening lending standards in the market for securities backed by mortgages on commercial buildings. Reflecting this tougher environment, some recent buyers of income real estate in Manhattan and elsewhere are adding equity to close on their purchases.   One reason for the continued parade of aggressive property deals is that money in the billions is pouring into real-estate funds run by the likes of Blackstone and Morgan Stanley, putting pressure on fund managers to invest. There was talk last week that Post Properties (PPS), another apartment REIT, might get a buyout bid.   In a research note last week, UBS REIT analyst Alexander Goldfarb estimated that the Archstone buyers may generate a return on their equity investment of just 1%, way below the risk-free rate of 5% on U.S. Treasuries and the double-digit returns sought by private-equity investors. Goldfarb makes some reasonable assumptions, including growth in net operating income of 6% in 2008.   The buyers will borrow $17.1 billion to purchase Archstone and put up $5.1 billion of equity, with Tishman Speyer contributing $250 million of equity and Lehman and Bank of America chipping in $4.85 billion. The interest tab on the $17 billion of debt could top $1 billion, exceeding this year's net operating income, which may total $800 million. "Given that the deal is more than 75% levered and interest expense would exceed net operating income, we believe the buyers may sell $8 billion or so of assets," Goldfarb wrote.   That was the strategy Blackstone pursued after it bought Equity Office Properties, the giant office REIT, in February for $39 billion. Faced with an enormous interest tab, Blackstone quickly flipped many of EOP's prime buildings, including nearly all of its Manhattan properties.   It's unclear how much benefit a private Archstone will derive from asset sales because of the high price being paid for the company. Apartment complexes rarely get sold for a capitalization rate of much less than 4%. The cap rate -- net operating income divided by the purchase price -- on the Archstone purchase is about 4.3%.   The country's hottest apartment market now is Manhattan, where rents at Archstone's several buildings run $3,000 to $4,500 a month for one-bedroom apartments and $5,000 to nearly $7,000 for two-bedroom units.   Manhattan cap rates are running below 4%, so a building that generates $7.5 million in annual income could be sold for $200 million. Its New York buildings are a major Archstone attribute, but represent just 12% of its net operating income. The Washington, D.C., market, Archstone's largest, accounts for about 35% of net operating income.     The REIT sector is finally starting to show some cracks, after an extraordinary seven-year run through 2006, when the REIT indexes topped the Standard & Poor's 500 each year and Morgan Stanley's MSCI REIT index tripled.   The MSCI index is down 2% year-to-date, after falling almost 15% from its February peak, around the time of the bidding war for Equity Office Properties. Wall Street lately has been spooked by higher rates and concerns over property-price inflation. The MSCI index was down over 4% last week.   Many investors saw a cautionary sign in the willingness of real-estate legend Sam Zell, chairman of EOP, to sell out to Blackstone. "Zell made one of the most timely sales in the history of his business," said Joe Rosenberg, chief investment strategist at Loews, in a recent speech ("The Best and the Brightest," Barron's, May 28). Zell said after the EOP sale that the deal didn't mark any top in real estate, but for Rosenberg, Zell "justified my abiding faith in the principle of 'Watch what they do, not what they say.'"   Rosenberg said office buildings are "one of the most overpriced asset classes" and that "the whole REIT business is an overpriced asset class." He said last week that "at the top of every bull market, there are always arguments to justify high prices." Among the bullish arguments for REITs now is that they are valued below the replacement cost of their assets. Whatever the merits of that view, REIT valuations are at near-record levels; overall dividend yields, which topped 8% early in the decade, have fallen to just 3.6%.   REITs are typically valued on two financial measures, funds from operations and adjusted funds from operations. FFO is a cash-flow measure that adds back depreciation to operating income, on the theory that depreciation is a phantom expense for REITs. The more conservative AFFO reflects outlays like leasing costs and ongoing capital expenditures that often don't get factored into FFO.   Archstone, the premier stock in the apartment sector, has one of the highest valuations in the $400 billion REIT market based on FFO and AFFO. Despite its attributes, including a strong pipeline of new developments, Archstone saw its shares come under pressure in early May after the company and others in the sector projected mildly disappointing growth in net operating income this year. On March 5, Barron's took a skeptical look at the other favorite in the apartment-REIT sector, AvalonBay Communities (AVB).   Bears on apartment REITs point to the weakening market for single-family homes as an ominous development. In some markets, like Florida, unsold condominiums are weighing on the rental market. Perversely, home-building stocks are down sharply this year, while apartment REITs are at near-record levels. Archstone counters that it is in the country's best markets, where rental apartments are scarce and renting can be cheaper than buying. In Manhattan, a two-bedroom apartment can cost $1 million, making a $5,000 monthly rental relatively attractive.   So with a lending landscape growing rougher and an economy showing signs of weakness, the REIT bull market may be nearing an end. Smart investors like Sam Zell are selling out, as are the well-regarded managers at Archstone. Given the financial underpinnings of the Archstone buyout, investors in the company's shares may soon go from hoping for a higher bid to simply wishing the current deal gets done.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 00:06 ET (04:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Official: Govt Should Sell Rostelecom With Svyazinvest -Tass
Story: MOSCOW (Dow Jones)--Russia's Federal Property Agency thinks the government should privatize telecommunications holding OAO Svyazinvest together with long-distance operator OAO Rostelecom (ROS), news agency Prime-Tass reported Saturday, citing the agency's director Valery Nazarov.   Svyazinvest's privatization is aimed at attracting new investments and Rostelecom is also in need of investment, Nazarov said.   He said that if the government choses to spin Rostelecom off from Svyazinvest, it would have to invest its own funds in Rostelecom's development, whereas Svyazinvest would fetch a better price if privatized together with Rostelecom.   The government has 75% minus one share in Svyazinvest, with the remainder held by fixed-line operator OAO Comstar United TeleSystems (CMST.LN), a subsidiary of conglomerate OAO AFK Sistema (SSA.LN).    Russian media reported last month that the government was considering spinning off Rostelecom from Svyazinvest in order to retain control over the long-distance carrier should it eventually go ahead with Svyazinvest's long-delayed privatization.   Sistema has said it would support such a move.   Agency Web site: http://www.prime-tass.com   -By Moscow Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +7 495 974 8055     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 08:22 ET (12:22 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/11) Hard Times Ahead At The Mall -2-
Story: Q: That's brave of you.   A: Amazon is a terrific company, no question. And oddly we once owned it. But we think the valuation here is excessive and their very solid recent quarter has led to dramatic expectations for earnings leverage. Those are expectations we do not believe can be delivered upon.     Q: Why not?   A: They are losing some customers such as Toys "R" Us and Borders Group [BGP]. Those weren't big profit drivers but they helped Amazon get to scale. Amazon is pursuing new categories for growth, which is a little bit like building more stores versus comp-store sales. Again, that's not necessarily bad but, it is a less profitable way to grow. Their competitive advantage of selling online is not growing, even while their business is growing.   Most importantly, there is a natural limit to their operating margin potential given the product categories they are in. Given the ease of online price-comparison shopping, Amazon is not going to have 20% operating margins selling books and music and general merchandise because, while they will have very loyal customers who are price insensitive, it is just too easy -- three mouse clicks -- to get to a cheaper way to buy the new bestseller. That will put a break on some of their margin expansion, even as they continue to grow their scale. Their ballpark 5% operating margins have room to grow, but we do not believe those margins can ever exceed 10%, and it will be a Herculean task moving them towards 10%.   To make this a cheap stock, margins would have to triple. Amazon is trading at a P/E of 72 times '07 estimates and 53 times '08 estimates. It is trading over 30 times Ebitda. Those multiples are higher than Google's [GOOG], and that is striking. As they raise prices to drive the incremental margin, they are going to lose some of their customers. We also believe their customer-service edge is not as sharp as it once was. As a result, it is going to take too many years of revenue growth to grow into this valuation.     Q: There's a lot of consolidation going on? Aren't you worried about a takeover?   A: At $30 billion in market value with the multiples it trades at, we think there are very few companies that could even begin to consider that, and so we are willing to take that risk.     Q: Thanks, Shawn.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 00:08 ET (04:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/11) The New Math Of Oil And Gas
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Dimitra DeFotis   It sounds too good to be true: pay a reasonable price for an asset that delivers juicy, tax-deferred yields, in a sexy sector, with the possibility of skyrocketing price appreciation.   This is the glitter of publicly traded master limited partnerships in the energy business -- and lately they have proven to be true gushers. Many have paid out dividends of 6% in the past year and appreciated about 30%. But now, with the market looking toppy -- an index of 50 MLPs is upnearly 100% in the past five years -- it's time for investors to get more selective.   While many of the energy partnerships have been created for companies in the pipeline business, outfits specializing in exploration and production are starting to get into the act and may offer better value. The best play of all could be the stocks of smaller exploration and production outfits that might benefit from spinning off some of their assets as MLPs.   Investors in these stocks could enjoy gains of 15% to 40% as the parent companies unlock the value of oil and gas fields.   Master limited partnerships, designed to encourage reinvestment in natural resources, pay no federal income taxes and distribute most of their free cash flow as dividends; they now offer yields of about 6%. Investors have been gobbling up the instruments, with the market value of MLPs surging threefold, to about $140 billion, since 2000, according to an estimate by brokerage Stifel Nicolaus.   Any rise in bond yields could hurt MLPs, since the partnerships serve as bond substitutes. But there looks to be more opportunity in the still-developing market for exploration-and-production MLPs. "The market is looking for new ways to value old assets, and that shift is just beginning to happen in energy exploration and production," says Gil Yang, an analyst at Citigroup Global Markets. "There is interest in chasing yield."   Consider Forest Oil (ticker: FST). In the limited partnership market, a company's daily energy production usually is valued at about $200,000 per barrel. But Forest Oil's production is valued at just $60,000 per barrel. That creates the opportunity for "significant valuation arbitrage," says Yang.   Colorado-based Forest, with a market value of $2.5 billion, could seize that opportunity by selling off certain assets into an MLP. Yang figures that the company's shares would rise by $8 apiece, or 20%, if it created an MLP for its Permian Basin fields in West Texas. That gain assumes the company would not only reap proceeds from the sale, but also retain an interest in the partnership and benefit from appreciation.   Forest has said it will consider MLPs as a way to create value, though it hasn't announced specific plans. Even if the company doesn't proceed with an MLP, it faces good prospects: Analysts see earnings rising 15% in 2008.   Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD), with a market value of $6.2 billion, may put as much as $500 million of assets into master limited partnerships over the coming year. And that may be only a start: The investment firm Friedman, Billings, Ramsey figures that more than 90% of Pioneer's assets would be ideal for MLPs. With a significant ownership stake in future partnerships, Texas-based Pioneer could see its shares climb 40%, Friedman Billings calculates. Even without the partnerships, analysts see Pioneer's earnings rising 18% in 2008.   Pioneer has said that one asset it plans to place in a partnership is its Spraberry oil and gas field in West Texas. In an MLP, the reserves in that field likely would have double the value they'd  be accorded under a traditional corporate umbrella, according to Citigroup.   "If investors get in during the early part of the U.S. MLP-creation cycle, they have the opportunity to profit," says Robert Gillon, an analyst at the energy research firm John S. Herold.   Among existing master limited partnerships with growth potential is Kinder Morgan Energy Partners (KMP), which has a sizable market value of $12 billion and boasts a 6% yield. The company's businesses are largely fee-oriented, ranging from services it provides to pipelines it controls, making its yield more reliable should oil prices drop.   The partnership trades at a below-average 13.4 multiple of enterprise value (market cap plus net debt) to-Ebitda (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, a measure of cash flow). Eaton Vance  recommends it to the firm's private clients because a number of Kinder Morgan's pipeline investments should support growth in cash flow and yield in the future, including a major natural-gas pipeline under construction from Colorado to the Midwest, says Charles Gaffney, an energy analyst at the firm.     Investing in any energy asset requires a bullish long-term outlook on oil, which seems to have found a comfort zone near $60 a barrel, and last week spiked above $67 before settling around $66. It also requires confidence that natural-gas prices won't return to the lows they once saw near $2 per million British thermal units. Declines in commodity prices could hurt producer MLPs more than pipeline players, though the best managements can hedge their production to insure against precipitous commodity-price drops.   Success for any exploration and production MLP would require continued production growth. That's a tall order, but as new MLPs add assets from parent corporations and make outside acquisitions, they can bump up output and raise dividends.   Investors who don't want to pick through dozens of partnerships can invest in exchange-traded funds like Tortoise Energy Infrastructure (TYG), which invests primarily in energy MLPs and yields roughly 5%. While the fund isn't cheap -- it trades at a 9% premium to its net asset value, according to ETFConnect.com -- it offers broad exposure. In the past year, it's outpaced the Alerian MLP Index, a measure of 50 prominent energy partnerships.   Forming an MLP may sound like putting old wine in new bottles. But sometimes a good bottle makes all the difference.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 00:04 ET (04:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Transneft CEO: To Borrow `Around $8B' In Benchmark Eurobond-2
Story: Transneft estimates the cost of the first stage of the pipeline - which is longer than the distance from New York to Los Angeles - at around $11 billion.   The costs of the project have risen sharply since its initial conception, and Transneft recently increased a related credit facility with savings bank OAO Sberbank by 15 billion rubles ($580 million) to RUB80 billion, according to materials in the prospectus for the Eurobond issue, the news agency Interfax reported earlier this week.   Earlier Saturday, Vaynshtok told a conference that Transneft has laid 950 kilometers of pipe to date, just under one-fourth of the total. It expects to commission the first stage by the end of 2008, he said.   He added that the company has already received throughput guarantees from producers for all of the pipe's planned capacity in its first stage, around 600,000 barrels a day. The pipeline's final throughput capacity is projected at 1.6 million barrels a day, shipping from Taishet in the province of Irkutsk to Nakhodka on the Pacific Ocean, with a separate spur leading to the Chinese city of Daqing.     Company Web site: http://www.transneft.ru     -By Geoffrey T. Smith, Dow Jones Newswires; (+7 985) 103  1191; geoffrey.smith@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 12:58 ET (16:58 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Dell CEO Sees Growth In Retail, Emerging Markets - Report
Story: ZURICH (Dow Jones)--Dell Inc. (DELL) plans an aggressive push into the retail personal computer market, investments into growing its services business, and wants to tap into emerging markets to reinforce growth, founder and chief executive Michael Dell said Saturday in a newspaper interview.   "There is a number of challenges, but we want to grow our $3.7 billion cash flow into a $7.3 billion cash flow as soon as possible," Dell said in an interview with Swiss daily Neue Zuercher Zeitung.   At present, Dell derives the bulk of its roughly $57 billion in annual revenue from sales to business clients, with sales to retail clients contributing only around 15% to the mix, he said, according to the paper.   Dell returned as chief executive in January to turn the company around after it had lost its lead in PC shipments last year to Hewlett-Packard Co. (HPQ). As part of the new strategy, he has reshaped the company's management team and signed a deal to sell desktops in Wal-Mart Stores Inc. (WMT) outlets. Dell is known for selling PCs directly via telephone or Internet.   This is just the first step of a broader retail push, he told the paper.   Michael Dell says future growth in the PC market will come from sales in emerging economies.   "Today, we have around one billion PCs globally, and that number will rise to around two billion in a few years," he said, according to the paper.   The second billion PCs won't be sold to the same clients, but to new consumers in China, India, Russia, Turkey, in the Middle East, Africa and Latin America, he added.   "For this, we need new products, including smaller and smarter devices," he told the paper.   The computer-maker also plans to expand the business of selling computers through stores.   Wal-Mart is a first step, but "in the next 12 to 18 months we plan around 20 more such steps," the CEO said.   Dell won't stop selling computers directly to consumers, but is setting up an additional sales channel to reach more customers and sell more, to grow both distribution channels in parallel.   In the longer run, Dell may also consider making other electronic devices that are similar to PCs, such as game consoles and handheld computers, he said.   "Today, there's still a pretty clear distinction between PCs and other devices, such as handhelds or phones, but with the new wireless technologies these barriers are becoming increasingly blurry," he added, according to the paper.   To accelerate growth in its business clients segment, Dell aims to push the sale of services, which currently contribute around $6 billion to revenue, Dell said.   Dell also said he plans to keep the chief executive post, which he had given up in 2004 to focus on the role as chairman of the board, for quite some time.   "I have a long-term horizon. I'm only 42, and still have a lot of plans for Dell," he said.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.nzz.com     -By Anita Greil, Dow Jones Newswires; +41 43 443 8044; anita.greil@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 06:25 ET (10:25 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(6/11) Profile: Eating Their Own Cooking
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Lawrence C. Strauss   Talking With   The Longleaf Funds Team     Since its founding in 1975, Memphis-based Southeastern Asset Management has earned a reputation for looking out for its mutual-fund shareholders. The no-load Longleaf Partners funds don't have 12b-1 or exit fees, and the advisory firm's employees are required to have all of their equity holdings in the funds.   "We are not doing something separate in our own personal accounts to offset the risk in the funds," says overseas-based E. Andrew McDermott, a portfolio manager at Southeastern who specializes in international stocks.   Among the feathers in Southeastern's cap is praise from David Swensen, Yale's chief investment officer and a big critic of actively managed funds for their inability to beat their benchmarks when fees are included. In his book Unconventional Success, Swensen asserts that the firm "exemplifies every fundamentally important, investor-friendly characteristic conducive to active-management success."   That includes being aware of tax consequences, making concentrated stock bets with conviction, and, when necessary, shutting the doors to new investors. Indeed, two of the funds -- Longleaf Partners (ticker: LLPFX), a mid- to large-cap portfolio, and Longleaf Partners Small-Cap (LLSCX) -- are now closed. But a third, Longleaf Partners International (LLINX), reopened about a year ago.   International had been closed in early 2004, when cash poured in and the managers had trouble putting all of it to work. "We were finding very few qualifying ideas and, therefore, our cash position got close to 30%," says McDermott, one of the fund's managers.   But last July, the managers decided to reopen the fund, convinced that enough good opportunities existed abroad. "It reduced our price-to-value ratio for the whole fund," says O. Mason Hawkins, Southeastern's chief executive officer, who also helps run all three funds. (The international fund was originally launched in 1998, when many investors were gobbling up richly valued tech stocks.)   While each of the three funds focuses on a different part of the market, their investment philosophies are identical -- "business, people and price," in Hawkins' words. We want a terrific business, managed by very honorable and capable people."   Hewing to a value, buy-and-hold approach, Southeastern uses various measures to gauge a company's fair value: discounted cash flow, liquidation value and, based on an internal database, the concern's estimated worth if it were private. "They should all check out with each other," says McDermott.   There are variations on these themes.   Financial-services firms, for example, are measured on their book value.   When the portfolio managers and analysts agree on a company's fair value, they want to buy it at least a 40% discount.   In addition to the firm's employees, Hawkins, McDermott and portfolio manager G. Staley Cates are "owner-operators," with lots of their own money in the funds. "When everybody around the table is going to have their net worth going into the next marginal name, it gets vetted better than if we weren't all owners," says Hawkins.   With about $42 billion under management, Southeastern, an independent firm, has managers spread across several generations, which would presumably prepare it for an eventual leadership transition. Hawkins, 59, has been there since 1975. Cates, 42, came aboard in 1986, and McDermott, 37, joined in 1998.   The international fund does invest in some U.S. companies, including Dell (DELL) and Yum Brands (YUM); such stocks pass Southeastern's screen test if at least half of the company's revenues are generated from outside the U.S. or if at least half of its value comes from abroad.   This portfolio typically has 18 to 22 names. "You can be adequately diversified with 12 companies if they are in different industries," says Hawkins. "And no one has been able to logically present a case for why your 30th- or 40th-best investment would be better than concentrating your money in, say, the top 12 or 18 names." As of March 31, the fund's top 10 holdings accounted for nearly 60% of its portfolio.   The goal of the fund, whose assets total $3.5 billion, is an annual return at least 10 percentage points above the inflation rate. From November 1998, shortly after its launch, through May of this year, the fund had an annual return of 16.33%, versus 8.90% for the MSCI EAFE, according to Morningstar. Its year-to-date return of 16.55% bests the index by 4.99 percentage points, placing it in the top 3% of Morningstar's foreign large-value category.   Yet Hawkins readily admits that returns over the past several years haven't been as impressive, relative to the peer group. The international fund's three-year annual return of 17.71% trails the benchmark by 5.74 percentage points and ranks near the bottom of its category.   The fund also has a fairly hefty expense tab -- 1.59% at the end of the first quarter, putting it in the lower half of its Lipper peer group for expenses.   One thing that has hurt the fund is its decision to hedge some of its holdings against currency risk. Thus, unlike competitors that don't hedge, it hasn't been benefited as much from a weak U.S. dollar.   The managers don't get hung up on benchmarking. "We will invest based on where we find the values; we're not trying to match an index," says Hawkins. In addition, says McDermott, "we like these companies that are very well-capitalized, conservatively managed, but in competitively entrenched businesses."   One such holding is Nikko Cordial (8603.Japan), one of Japan's largest brokerage firms, whose shares the fund began snapping up late last year when the stock price was below 1,000 yen.   "They had a private-equity portfolio that was easy to value, and they had a large slug of excess capital that was worth about 200 yen a share," recalls McDermott, who is based in London, but frequently travels to Asia.   Southeastern believed that the stock was worth north of 1,900 yen, but an accounting problem had battered it. "It became more and more of a panic-selling situation," says McDermott. The company, however, was not delisted, as some investors had feared, and Citgroup (C) in April announced that it had completed a tender offer for a majority stake in Nikko Cordial. Late last week, the stock was at 1,686 yen.   Another big position is Cheung Kong Holdings (1.HongKong), a Hong Kong company with a sprawling portfolio of assets, including real estate in China, and a big stake in Hutchison Whampoa (HUWHY), whose holdings include port facilities, telecoms and property. The Longleaf team thinks Cheung Kong is worth 135 to 140 Hong Kong dollars a share, considerably higher than the HK$103.50 it was fetching late last week. Cheung Kong's chairman and founder is Li Ka Shing, whom Hawkins regards as a master long-term investor.   The fund's top U.S. holding is Dell, whose shares have disappointed in recent years. Plagued by management turnover, Dell now has Michael Dell back at its helm, a move Hawkins applauds. "The long-term growth for Dell in Europe and Asia is significant double-digit," he says.   The managers also see more upside in Olympus, (7733.Japan), the Japanese company known for its cameras but which has a growing business in endoscopic surgical instruments. "The future medical trends are all about minimally invasive surgery," says McDermott.   The fund bought the stock at around 2,000 yen but thinks it's worth about 5,000 yen. Late last week, it was at 4,610 yen.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 00:05 ET (04:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Russia UES CEO Sees Investment In Co This Yr Well Over $20B
Story: ST PETERSBURG (Dow Jones)--Investment in electricity monopoly RAO Unified Energy System of Russia (EESR.RS) will total well over $20 billion this year, the company's chief executive told journalists Saturday.   Speaking on the sidelines of a conference, Anatoly Chubais said that an estimate he made earlier this year of $20 billion to be attracted through share issues and other means "was a serious mistake...it will be much, much more."   UES has raised around $6 billion so far this year through its various restructuring operations, most notably the sale of stakes in three of its 20 thermal generation companies. This week, Italian utility Enel SpA (EN) agreed to pay $1.52 billion for a 25.03% stake in wholesale generator OAO OGK-5 (OGKE.RS).   Chubais said he expected the prices paid for such stakes to continue to rise, but didn't give any precise estimates. Enel's valuation of OGK-5 implied a value of around $660 a kilowatt of installed capacity.   The next scheduled sale is for a stake of just under 40% in OAO OGK-4 (OGKD.RS), a company of similar size to OGK-5. Chubais said Germany's E.On AG (EON), Finland's Fortum Oyj (FUM1V.HE) and OAO United Co. Rusal, the world's largest producer of primary aluminum, are all interested in the sale. Rusal and E.On were both disappointed bidders in this week's OGK-5 auction.   UES is due to be dissolved next year, with ownership of the thermal plants all passing into private hands, while ownership of the hydro plants and grids reverts, in the main, to the state.   Chubais dismissed suggestions that he would return to politics after leaving his job at UES. In response to suggestions that his knowledge of everything in the electricity sector would well qualify him to be its regulator, he replied: "No, no, no - I know everything about government too."     Company Web site: http://www.rao-ees.ru     -By Geoffrey T. Smith, Dow Jones Newswires; (+7 985) 103 1191; geoffrey.smith@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 06:49 ET (10:49 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/11) Follow-Up: Will The Russian Bear Maul BP?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Vito J. Racanelli   Everyone is familiar with the Russian matryoshka, those wooden dolls placed one inside another; as you pull the outside one apart, a similar but smaller one is found inside, and so on. U.K. oil giant BP might be forgiven for thinking its investment in Russia is coming to resemble a matryoshka.   On June 1, news reports said a Russian regulator postponed for two weeks a decision on whether to rescind the license for a huge Siberian gas field of TNK-BP Holding, a Russian venture owned 50% by BP. Some investors think the license will be revoked, though an accommodation is still possible.   While  the field hasn't contributed much so far, the regulatory snag could be a sign of broader problems ahead for TNK-BP, which accounts for some 25% of the British giant's production. Russia continues a policy of effectively nationalizing much of the country's oil-and-gas reserves, pushing around foreign oil firms.   TNK-BP has been faulted for failing to produce a required nine billion cubic meters yearly of natural gas for the local market by 2006. The company has responded that the lack of pipelines around the area makes the gas uneconomic so far.   TNK-BP has been BP's main source of production growth since 2003, when the company made what seemed to many then a risky investment in the Russian venture. Barron's argued  that the stock was cheap and that the move would pay off ("Renewable Energy," July 28, 2003). The American depositary receipts (ticker: BP) have returned 86% since then, beating both the Standard & Poor's 500 and the DJ Stoxx 50, of which BP is a member. Yet BP's stock price has badly trailed peers like ExxonMobil (XOM), the result of well-publicized refinery operational woes, among other problems.   While a loss of the Siberian license would be damaging to future gas production, investors are worried more broadly about "what can happen to TNK-BP from here on in," says Roberto Cominotto, an analyst at Bank Julius Baer. Though concerned about further Russian setbacks, he's kept his  Buy rating on the stock, which is held by the bank. Because sentiment is so poor, the market will be surprised when  BP  beats low guidance of less than 2% production growth over the next few years, he asserts.   Political problems are nothing new to Western oil giants, and BP constantly deals with getting oil out of dangerous places, says Neil Darke, head of research for brokerage firm Collins Stewart. At a price-earnings ratio of about 11 times consensus earnings estimates for this year, it still offers decent value, he adds.   BP's ADRs offer a nice dividend yield of 3.7%, too. Nevertheless, while a direct threat to TNK-BP from the Russian bear may be hard to imagine, the cautious investor would be wise to take some profits now and keep enough BP stock to profit from continued high oil prices.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 00:07 ET (04:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(6/11) Barron's Mailbag: Blank Disclosures
Story: (From BARRON'S)   To the Editor:     Regarding  "Keeping It Confidential," May 28: I don't think it is fair to the stockholders of a target company that the SEC allows confidential treatment to big-shot investors while they are accumulating a target company's shares. The target's stockholders, whose stock is now more valuable, could be selling it with incomplete knowledge for less than it's worth.   This is not fair to the little guy.   Sam Marx   Palm City, Fla.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 00:01 ET (04:01 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Gazprom Chaiman Confirms Interest In Kovykta Project -Report
Story: MOSCOW (Dow Jones)--Russia's OAO Gazprom (GSPBEX.RS) is interested in the Kovykta natural gas project currently operated by Russo-British oil venture TNK-BP (TNBP.RS), the gas monopoly's chairman, Dmitry Medvedev, confirmed Saturday, news agency RIA Novosti reported.   "This project is interesting to Gazprom, but no steps can be taken until administrative matters are settled," he said.   TNK-BP, half-owned by the U.K.'s BP Plc (BP), is widely expected to lose its license for Kovykta in the coming weeks after being unable to meet its production commitments.   Agency Web site: http://www.rian.ru   -By Moscow Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +7 495 974 8055     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 10:32 ET (14:32 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Sabic, Sinopec In Prelim Deal On $1B Petrochem Plant -Report
Story: BEIRUT (Zawya Dow Jones)-- Saudi Basic Industries Corp. (2010.SA), or Sabic, the largest petrochemical firm in the world in terms of market value, signed a preliminary agreement with China Petroleum & Chemical Corp. (SNP), or Sinopec, to invest $1 billion in a petrochemical plant in China, London-based daily Asharq al-Awsat reported Saturday.   The agreement, signed in late May, still requires the approval of the Chinese authorities and the investment will be equally divided between the two firms, the paper reported, citing people familiar with the situation.   According to the agreement, the two firms will set up a naphtha cracker unit to produce 1 million metric tons of ethylene a year in the northern Chinese city of Tianjin.   Sabic will also participate in setting up a polyethylene production line and a monoethylene glycol plant, the newspaper's sources said.   Earlier in May a Sabic official confirmed that his company was in talks over the $1 billion petrochemical joint-venture with Sinopec.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.asharqalawsat.com/     -By the Beirut bureau, Zawya Dow Jones, 961 1 985757, beirut@zawya.com    Copyright (c) 2007 ABQ Zawya Ltd.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  June 09, 2007 00:39 ET (04:39 GMT)
